TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) welcome the government's moves to protect the enforcement of human rights in response to the decision of the High Court in Brandy v the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and others. We support it and are gratified that the High Court handed down such a decision, which reinforces one of the few constitutional protections of human rights in Australia—the separation of powers. The separation of powers embodied in the constitution ensures that non-judicial persons cannot exercise judicial power. As a result of the Brandy case, the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Act that were passed in 1992 have been found to have never been valid.

PARA.TAB: We are pleased that, in response to this, the government set up what has come to be known as the Basten committee to look at restoring both the protection of human rights and the constitutionality of those provisions. We are less happy with the government's amendments under consideration here today, which revert to the pre-November 1992 arrangements. I will detail some of the concerns a little later.

Obviously, the decision in the Brandy case did throw into disarray somewhat the determinations that had already been made since the amendments that were moved in this chamber were found to have not been valid. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has stated that 37 determinations were made between the passage of the amendments and the handing down of the High Court's decision in the Brandy case. It is fortunate that the validity of those amendments was tested at such an early stage before the rights of more people were adversely affected through the passage of the invalid legislation.

It would be easy to attack the government and its legal advisers for introducing amendments to these acts that were so clearly unconstitutional. However, that is not the point. It is important that it is now the responsibility of the government to establish an effective and constitutionally valid mechanism for the protection of human rights.

In the short term, the government is simply amending the legislation to return to the situation before the 1992 amendments. While there is obviously a need to act rapidly, it is important that this be only a temporary measure. People may rightly say that we have not acted totally rapidly in this situation. Some measure of time has elapsed. My understanding is that the Basten committee has travelled quite a way down the path of providing some very good solutions to these problems. I certainly hope that that is the case.

I believe that the measures that are being introduced here as temporary measures cause some problems, because we are putting in place what was felt by everybody pre-November 1992 to be an utterly unsatisfactory and undesirable arrangement. To that end, one of the Greens' amendments relates to a sunset clause. I thank Senator Spindler for his comments on it and the indication from the Democrats that they felt we were a bit unrealistic in the date we had set. We could have thrown things into a bit of turmoil if our sunset clause had come up at the time when there could have been elections in the offing or when, in some such way, the results of the Basten committee could not have been brought to this place for proper consideration and discussion and be put into operation. So we have delayed that sunset clause stage until 1 September 1996.

Our reason for doing that was basically that there is a danger that, if we revert to the November 1992 position here, then it will stay like that for a long time. If there is an election and if there is a change of government or if there is the same government, there may be nothing that is a real incentive to look at the arrangements that were found to be so unsatisfactory then. That would be highly undesirable. The sunset clause stands in the place of an incentive to whomever is in government to redress what we believe to be a highly unsatisfactory situation.

The reason we believe it was never satisfactory is that the pre-November 1992 situation involved a double hearing which was adverse to the interests of the complainants. It also put them in difficulties with legal costs. It allowed their case to be available for scrutiny and we believe that is the reason why—and I know this will not be new to my colleagues in the chamber—the unsatisfactory and invalid amendments were put in place. It was to remedy what was found to be a very negative situation for complainants because of the lack of enforceability of determinations in the pre-1992 acts. It was that lack of enforceability which led the government to attempt to create an alternative process, which has subsequently been found to be unconstitutional by the High Court.

That is the reason why there are some other amendments which we believe are far more satisfactory as interim arrangements than the ones that are proposed in this bill. I regret to say that, apart from some measure of support from the Democrats, we have not gained support for this. So it may well largely be a flagging of what we believe is a far better option than the one proposed by the amendments. Even at this late stage, I would urge my colleagues to reconsider their capacity to support the amendments that the Greens are putting forward.

In our view, since the previous amendments and alternative process were found to be unconstitutional, we believe it is clear that determinations by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission cannot be used as an enforcement mechanism. A court mechanism must now be established. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre in Sydney has advocated the establishment of a `Human Rights Court'. Without wishing to pre-empt the recommendations of the Basten committee, the Greens (WA) would support the establishment of such a court. We made this statement in March this year, and we make it again now: this would give human rights and their protection the status that they require and which have been lacking to date.

Under both the pre- and post-1992 schemes, persons whose human rights had been infringed could not go directly to the Federal Court for enforcement. They had to go through the conciliation and determination process conducted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. For many people, this would be seen as further barriers to the enforcement of their human rights. While HREOC has an admirable record in conciliating disputes, it is essential that any future regime allows people direct access to a court.

We understand the difficulties faced by persons seeking to enforce their human rights and the differentials in power and resources between the victims and the perpetrators of human rights abuses. As a consequence, the government must ensure that the mechanisms in such a court are free from undue formality and legalism. It must also ensure that there is adequate legal aid and other support for people seeking to protect their human rights.

The legislation which this parliament has enacted to protect human rights is a good first step; however, there has never been in place the necessary enforcement mechanisms that we believe are required. This interim situation, the one which I believe is being supported here today, is highly unsatisfactory. I urge my colleagues to consider the value of the Greens' amendments in which we suggest that an option be available to a complainant either to stay within the conciliation and determination provisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, in full knowledge that there is not an enforcement capacity, or to choose to go direct to the Federal Court after the completion of the conciliation part of the process.

In our view, that option actually removes the criticism that was involved in the double hearing, and we believe that that would have been a far better interim arrangement to be putting in place at this point in time—especially if there is as much reluctance about supporting the sunset clause as there is about supporting our mechanisms for the interim arrangement. There is no incentive on any government to redress this highly undesirable situation.

In conclusion, I believe the government should not miss this opportunity to provide an effective and powerful mechanism for the protection of human rights. That is even more significantly important today—the day we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Racial Discrimination Act and the significant step forward it represents in the protection of human rights for the people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been implied, and perhaps explicit, criticism of the Attorney-General's Department in the course of this debate. Senator Chamarette has taken the government to task for not developing a regime that is fair and expeditious, which can be used at reasonable cost, in which there is not undue formality and which protects human rights. She is right to want those sorts of things. They are put again and again to the Attorney-General. People want a particular regime; they want to achieve things that are good to achieve.

PARA.TAB: The Attorney-General and the people who work in the department who have given outstanding advice, not only to the government but generally over the years, have been asked to try to accommodate that. If the Attorney-General's Department never worked out a scheme which would accommodate the sorts of things that Senator Chamarette requires, then it would never make a mistake. If we want to see what the limit of constitutional power is for the Commonwealth—so as to accommodate good legislation; so as to make Australia a fairer place; so as to bring human rights within the ken of people who live in this country—we have got to test what it is that is constitutional.

Nobody knows what is constitutional until a matter comes before the court. Even the High Court does not know what is constitutional until a matter is put before it. I suggest that people look at the judgment of Justice Brennan, as he then was—Chief Justice Brennan, as he now is—in the case of Theophanous and the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd when he goes into this very point of how the law develops. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Common law is amenable to development by judicial decision, subject to the Constitution and to statute. What is permissible development of the common law by the courts and what amounts to impermissible change is an issue on which minds differ most sharply.
That is the common law. Then Chief Justice Brennan talks about the constitution. He states:

Clearly the Court cannot change the Constitution, nor can it convert constitutional silence into a legal rule with constitutional force. I do not mean that, in changing conditions, the Constitution does not have a changing effect . . . that the denotation of its terms does not change . . . that the course of judicial interpretation does not reveal that a past constitutional doctrine is untenable . . . or that new situations do not reveal new doctrines inherent in the constitutional text. The Constitution speaks continually to the present and it operates in and upon contemporary conditions.

I see some representatives of the Attorney-General's Department are here today. I know that they are people of outstanding legal ability, of great integrity and of great patience, particularly when they come before Senate committees. Those people are testing again and again, on the request of government, how far we can go to make Australia a better society, a fairer society and a more just society.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, given the sorts of things that Justice Brennan, as he then was—he is now Chief Justice—said and given the sorts of things that Senator Chamarette and others have said before about the need for a new regime, people have to go out and give things a go. If they do that, they might make a mistake. Given all that, the Attorney-General's Department should not be criticised for the result in Brandy's case. It is unfair to take it to task for doing what the government and what this parliament wants it to do. It was this parliament which passed the legislation that was held invalid in Brandy's case. What we should be doing instead is marking the debt we owe to the great advice we get from the Attorney-General's Department.

One example of how much we owe the department is the Native Title Act, which was challenged in the High Court and which the High Court upheld. The High Court could have gone the other way on that but it upheld that act, which has advanced Australia's standing as a fair and just society in a very big way indeed. I conclude my remarks by saying it is good to see the Attorney-General's representatives here. They have done a great job and will continue to do so in years to come.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond on behalf of the government to some of the issues raised in the debate. My colleague Senator Cooney has already made a response to some of the issues raised in the debate. I thank him for that contribution in particular.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the suggestion from Senator Vanstone that the fate of the scheme invalidated the Brandy decision indicates that the government is receiving poor quality legal advice, I make the point that the area of judicial power in the constitution is a very complex one and the High Court has great difficulty in defining the concept. In enacting the former scheme, the government had legal advice from eminent lawyers such as the former chief general counsel in the Attorney-General's Department—a well recognised expert in constitutional law. The scheme was also supported by, for example, Sir Ronald Wilson, currently President of the HREOC and a former High Court judge. When one deals with complex novel areas of the law there will be a divergence in views, and the High Court is of course the final arbiter.

The suggestion was also made during the debate that the legal advice provided to the government should be made available to the parliament. Legal advice is made available to the government of the day not the parliament, and it is for the government to make it available to the parliament if it is appropriate.

It was also suggested by Senator Abetz that the government should have permanently resolved this issue by now. I would point out to the Senate that on 27 February 1995, only four days after the High Court handed down its decision, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) announced the government's two-stage response to the decision. Firstly, as an urgent interim measure, it was decided to reinstate the pre-1993 scheme so that the determinations of the HREOC could be enforced. The government has been endeavouring to introduce these amendments since March. Secondly, the review committee which had been examining the role and structure of the HREOC was expanded and given the task of considering the options for a new permanent scheme and reporting to the government by June 1995.

The committee chaired by Colin Neave in the Attorney-General's Department was expanded to include John Basten QC, Dr Sue Kenny and the Law Reform Commissioner Chris Sidoti. The Attorney-General also announced on 22 February 1995 that there would be consultation of any proposal before it went to the government.

The committee has considered several options. A draft proposal has been developed and consultations have been held with a wide variety of interest groups. These consultations have included: on 9 May, government departments and agencies; on 12 May, relevant agencies of state and territory governments; also on 12 May, a wide variety of non-government organisations; on 19 May, the ACTU and business and industry groups; and, on 23 May, the Law Council.

The proposal has also been the subject of consultations with the coalition, the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine. The committee has also received a wide range of written submissions and will shortly finalise the proposal. A report will be provided to the government by July 1995.

Senator Abetz has also raised a question as to whether, under proposed section 105B of the government amendments, respondents would be able to receive legal or financial assistance to defend themselves against a frivolous or vexatious claim. As is provided for under proposed subsection 105B(1) paragraph B, a respondent would be able to apply for such assistance. If he or she were able to satisfy the Attorney-General that it would involve hardship to the person to refuse the application, and that it is reasonable in all the circumstances, assistance could be granted. A decision in these cases would be made on a case by case basis.

The government welcomes the debate. On behalf of the government, I wish to remind the Senate and the community of the purpose of this bill. This bill amends the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 and other human rights legislation to implement the recommendations of the initial report of the joint review of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That report made recommendations relating to resource utilisation, corporate performance and the structure of the HREOC.

The key amendments to the HREOC Act is to provide that the responsibility for the management of the commission is vested in the commission as a body corporate with a chief executive office of powers to be delegated by it to an executive director appointed by the commissioner under the Public Service Act. This means that all powers of the secretary under the Public Service Act will be removed from the Human Rights Commissioner and settled upon the President and commissioners collectively.

The government has also moved amendments which respond to the consequences of the High Court's decision in Brandy versus Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and Others on 23 February, which held that the mechanisms for the enforcement of determinations for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, other than determinations made effecting respondents who are Commonwealth agencies, was constitutionally invalid.

These amendments amend the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, and the Privacy Act 1988 to reinstate the procedure for the enforcement of the determinations made by the commission as it operated prior to 1992. This will operate as an interim measure pending the development of a new mechanism to enforce determinations of the commission to replace that which was held to be invalid.

New amendments have also been moved by the Greens (WA) to allow direct access to the Federal Court and for a sunset clause. We do not believe it is appropriate that the Commonwealth legislation establishing enforcement procedures in Australian courts should be subject to any clause which automatically, by lapse of time, extinguishes individual rights to access the courts and human rights cases. It is always open to the parliament to revisit and amend the legislation at any time if the parliament so decides. For this reason the government will oppose those amendments.

As to the second amendment proposed by the Greens (WA), we are also concerned that major expenditure would be required if the Federal Court Act were amended to confer jurisdiction on the court to hear these cases from the outset. Given the large number of cases that might be filed under such a procedure, the delays in recruitment of court staff and the court accommodation problems could be significant. The high cost of filing fees, the adversarial system and the lack of any special procedures to handle discrimination cases make this proposal quite inappropriate. The government notes the contribution of all honourable senators. I commend the bill to the Senate as a worthwhile step to improve the operation of HREOC and to provide an effective and necessary interim solution to the Brandy decision.

As I have indications that there is not sufficient support for these amendments in the chamber, I will not be calling a division as I do not wish to delay the time of the chamber. I sincerely regret that there is not sufficient support to make the arguments against the government's position stronger. I believe that the government has not adequately addressed an interim arrangement that meets the needs of the complainants who will be disadvantaged by a reversion back to the pre-November 1992 arrangements.

PARA.TAB: These amendments deal with the option that I am presenting on behalf of the Greens (WA). Instead of reverting to the situation where a complainant to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission has an enforced double hearing which allows their arguments to be heard and which gives an undue advantage and a shift in the power balance to the person against whom they are making the complaint, our option is that at the end of the conciliation process the complainants are given a choice. They can say, `I want to proceed through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission process from conciliation to determination in full awareness that there isn't an enforceability capacity within the commission to do that.' I am not a lawyer—my legal colleagues may be more aware of this than I am—but my understanding is that, if people have proceeded through a conciliation process and they are coming to an almost mutually agreeable solution with the people whom they have the complaint against, they can suddenly decide that it is likely to be resolved without the need for enforcement. Therefore, there is no harm in proceeding at this level and taking that into consideration. It may also be that the penalty and the likelihood of the people whom they have the complaint against not agreeing with that response are so small that they would feel that it would be a waste of time and energy to go to the Federal Court. That option remains available to them. They can proceed to that point.

The purpose of one of the amendments is to give people the option of either proceeding through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission or, at the point that conciliation is completed, electing to go straight to the Federal Court for a proper consideration of their case for the first time. They can get a determination which will have the enforcement provisions of the judicial framework.

Giving the complainant that option, in my view, redresses the disadvantage that remains here, which is that double hearing option. They get a determination and then they go to the Federal Court where that can be challenged. I believe there is also a problem with the double provision of any legal aid support. There is another financial disadvantage in the position we are reinstating now.

I have a third option, but I did not write it into the amendments. I will describe it at this point. In that first option where people elect to go straight through with the commission from the conciliation to the determination process, if a contract is made during that determination process between the two parties there might be some capacity to register that contract in the arbitration court without contravening the constitutionality question of the separation of powers being violated. That is a finer point. I am not going to expand on it because I understand I do not have the support of the opposition on these amendments. The government has already indicated its stance. I would seek a comment from the opposition to this—

TALK.START.PARA: —They could make an agreement to arbitrate.

—Yes, and I thank Senator Abetz for his interjection. The finer point that could be made on a complainant remaining with the human rights commission, even in the absence of that enforceability, would be that they could make a mutual agreement to arbitrate and seal their agreement in the arbitration court. This would thereby move the enforcement capacity from the arbitration court to the contract or agreement that has been made.

PARA.TAB: I believe my amendments are very worth while and creative responses to what has been an unsatisfactory situation. All I can do is seek the support of my colleagues in this chamber to the amendments I have just moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have carefully considered the amendments moved by the Greens. If Senator Chamarette had been prepared to accept our amendment, which would have been to make sure that both parties agreed to go straight to the Federal Court, the complainant as well as the respondent, we would have supported the Greens' amendments. In the circumstances, we do not feel that one party should be able to take the case to a court with the inevitable greater expenditure of money, time and energy. The Democrats, as a result, will not be supporting these three amendments.

—I am sorry that I omitted to mention my response to Senator Spindler's suggestion that the Democrats would be willing to support our amendments if we had agreed with their further amendment. The problem I see with that is that the purpose of our amendments is to retain the support of the human rights commission with the complainant and not to have them disadvantaged by the double hearing. If the option we are providing can occur only with the support of the party that might be the problem that caused the person to choose to go to the Federal Court, it is self-defeating.

PARA.TAB: We are trying to combat a power imbalance that the current situation allows and shift it back to being with the person who has the legitimate grievance that has been heard through the conciliation process. The Democrats' amendment puts the power back with the other party in the same way that a double hearing does. While I appreciate the concerns that Senator Spindler has, it would really nullify the point of our amendments. That is why we have not been able to accept the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's position is that there is subject matter worthy of attention in the Greens' amendments and it does not dismiss them out of hand. The Basten committee has been set up, and the coalition's view is that the recommendations from that committee should be looked at and then a position adopted after those recommendations have been handed down. When that is done, we will certainly look at the Greens' amendments as part of the overview that the coalition will conduct at that stage, but we believe it would be premature at this stage to adopt them.

PARA.TAB: There are some aspects of the amendments which I find reasonably attractive, such as the choice of which avenue to take—the court or the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission—but there are one or two aspects which we have trouble with there. Nonetheless, that is the coalition's view and we will be opposing these amendments for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I pass on from that, I ask the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) for some statistics relating to how many people have been going through the court system. I did have those figures in my file. I do not have them with me, but my memory of them is that only a relativity small number have needed to go on to the determination stage each year.

PARA.TAB: I want to challenge the minister's criticism of our amendments that the costs would be too high for two reasons. One reason is that I would like, as a way of guiding us, some evidence of those costs and what the expectations would be in relation to the previous figures of complaints that have gone either through the conciliation process or to the determination stage.

Secondly, I make the point that, if we simply say the costs of the arrangement being suggested by the Greens are too high and we cannot afford to give legal aid or support to people to go through that means, we are admitting that the interim solution becomes the cheap option, and it is a cheap option where the complainant bears the cost. That is outrageous.

We ought to be looking at how well we can address the human rights concerns of the people who are making complaints to the commission; we should not be evaluating this in terms of the cheapness or the lack of costs of the mechanisms that might be provided. It is a double thing. I express concern that that is a main argument against our provision. I also want some evidence that that is the case and that it is substantially more expensive—not that I will necessarily agree with it even if it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the committee has been served quite well by the Greens' amendments, and they have given us food for thought. DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE AMENDMENT BILL 1995DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1995DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1995 and related bills aim to set up a new dairy market support arrangement in Australia. Essentially, this legislation replaces the old dairy legislation which was found to be illegal under GATT. Importantly, it will continue the phase-out of assistance to the dairy industry. I am pleased, therefore, that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, has come on duty to take important note of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The old legislation aimed to phase down assistance to the equivalent of a five per cent tariff by the year 2000. Based on a levy paid by dairy farmers on all milk, this money was pooled and used to assist export returns. The objective was to encourage companies to export rather than dump their product on the domestic market and risk forcing down prices. Under GATT, this assistance was seen as an export subsidy and therefore illegal.

Industry, government and the coalition agreed that new legislation was needed—legislation that not only continued the phase-out of assistance but met Australia's obligations under GATT. Priorities for the federal coalition were the continuation of benefits to the dairy industry and a minimum of disruption to consumers and manufacturers. This package meets our criteria.

It sets out a new levy on market milk, as opposed to all milk, and should amount to no more than the current levy. It will be based on protein and fat content rather than just fat content. The new levy will be paid by farmers supplying market milk. It is GATT legal because market milk is not generally regarded as an export oriented product. Under the new arrangement, manufacturers will pay a levy on domestic manufactured products instead of farmers paying a levy on the milk used in manufacture. These funds will be redistributed to farmers based on the amount of manufactured milk, as opposed to market milk, supplied. It means that assistance will now be identifiable as a domestic market support scheme rather than an export subsidy scheme.

It is important to note that the effective phase down will continue at the same rate as the old legislation. The new scheme will terminate on 30 June in the year 2000 and any surplus funds will go to the Australian Dairy Corporation. The federal coalition sees no reason for the price of domestic dairy products to rise. The new arrangements simply transfer the levy paid on all milk to market milk and product.

However, because the levy will be based on protein and fat content, there may be minor adjustments in the level of payments to individual farmers. ABARE, along with the Australian Dairy Corporation, will estimate the annual level of support under the 1992 plan, to enable the government to set an appropriate rate for the levy.

The import offset provisions in this legislation will protect the amount of dairy market support flowing to milk producers in manufacturing. Without these, the system could be manipulated to gain unfair financial advantage. In other words, someone could export dairy produce that has already been imported or displaced from the domestic market and then claim an export rebate without paying the manufacturing levy. Therefore, an import-offset levy payable by direct importers, and an acquisition-offset levy payable by manufacturers acquiring product from importers who have not paid the import offset levy, will be imposed on an annual assessment basis. These levies do not represent a surrogate import levy; they are applied only against the export rebate. This conforms with the GATT-legal principle that indirect taxation costs on production can be legally rebated.

The dairy industry is unquestionably one of Australia's great success stories. Just 10 years ago, the government was worried that, if the industry produced more than six billion litres of milk a year, we would have a glut and prices would fall. But thanks to the outward-looking nature of this industry, we are about to produce and sell more than eight billion litres of milk this year. Export income alone is expected to top $1.4 billion.

Australia has gone from a country giving daily milk deliveries to a country where dairy products have use-by dates that are the envy of the world. The industry has achieved this through hard work and a commitment to quality assurance. It controls the quality of the product from the cow in the paddock to the plate in the house, thereby ensuring Australia's world reputation for high quality dairy products. Dairying is an industry in which growers can value add and look after their interests past the farm gate. Around 70 per cent of all milk produced in this country is handled by dairy farmer cooperatives. Despite some early problems with undercapitalisation, the industry has aggressively developed branded products, particularly specialised products for niche markets, and profitability has improved. This in turn has attracted investment, and investment has grown.

The legislation before us complements the dairy industry both domestically and internationally. It will set up a new market support arrangement as well as meet our obligations under GATT. The federal Liberal and National parties join the government in supporting this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we see now is yet another example of where Australian laws have to be changed to accord with the new international trade regime. For all the jumping up and down that occurs in relation to treaties, there is no other treaty that Australia has ever signed that imposes more laws, restrictions and changes on Australian laws than the Uruguay Round of GATT—now the World Trade Organisation.

PARA.TAB: The changes in these bills are required to implement the new policy to replace the current dairy market support arrangements so that they are consistent with Australia's commitments to the World Trade Organisation agreement. The package of this bill replaces the old market support fund with a new domestic market support fund for milk producers. The purpose of this new scheme, the domestic market support fund, is to give manufacturing milk producers the same level of support as under the old scheme that was against the World Trade Organisation.

The support for manufacturing milk producers is to be funded by the market milk levy, which is charged to market milk producers, and the manufacturing milk levy, which is paid for by domestic consumers and levied on the manufacturers. I certainly hope this bill does perform the function that it is expected to perform.

I have received a briefing today on yet another bill, the Trade Marks Bill, which was introduced hurriedly in the World Trade Organisation package and which was put together so hastily. Before it even comes to fruition it will have to be completely rewritten. It is a very complex bill, and we will be asked to deal with it in some detail at very short notice. The way we changed our legislation worries me. It worries me that we did not debate this whole concept last year. I guess this whole debate will occur again when we are required a little later to deal with the complex Trade Marks Bill.

The main reason I speak today briefly is to put on the record that this is yet another example of how Australia's law is being dictated by the World Trade Organisation in an area where either house of parliament has not seen fit to have a proper debate at the time we took on these commitments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to comment on Senator Margetts's views about the World Trade Organisation. I know that she is at variance with the vast majority of this chamber and the vast majority in the other place. I do intend to make a few comments, however, on the arrangements into which we are entering by virtue of the passage of this legislation and the reason for doing so. We are amending our legislation so that it is consistent with the requirements of the World Trade Organisation and the Uruguay Round of GATT.

PARA.TAB: I make it very clear that some of us wonder why we bother when some of our friends are not abiding by the rules. It is a matter of great concern amongst the dairy industry in Queensland and elsewhere around Australia that some of our very close friends, most notably the United States, are busy dumping milk powder products into the Philippines market. This is a market which we have supplied for a long period, a market in which we have a very firm hold, a market where there was no subsidy from the Europeans and a market into which, as a result of dairy subsidies in the US, milk powder product is being dumped. The Americans cannot say they are doing this to counter the threat of European subsidies. If they are honest, they must admit that this will lead to only a further breakdown in the objective of unsubsidised free trade throughout this region.

As Senator Tambling said so eloquently here today, the dairy industry is worth $1.4 billion to this country. It is very important that our producers get a fair return on their exports. It is absolutely critical. It is critical to the stability of the price of the domestic market. We are a very efficient producer of dairy products. We have to export those products in order to ensure that we get a decent price in Australia—that is what all the arrangements have been about—and, even when we do so, we can get them into markets cheaper than local producers overseas. I have seen that in supermarkets overseas.

It riles me and the industry immensely when this sort of thing happens because all it does is reduce our return and reduce the value of the dairy industry around the world. That is the consequence of the American arrangements. As I said to the dairy industry in North Queensland last month when I opened its conference, it is important that we ensure, through whatever means possible, the message is taken to the Americans that their actions are unsatisfactory. I hope Senator Collins has done that this week. I hope to have an opportunity to do so myself.

It is also important that in the long run we develop a market overseas for fresh milk and fresh dairy products, which we can supply at an advantage compared with the rest of the world. Our proximity and the good air communications between Australia and many other countries mean that we can get fresh product into the market cheaper, more efficiently and more quickly than any of our competitors. That ultimately is the long-term future for the Australian industry. It is tied to growing living standards overseas so that people can afford fresh product instead of a powdered product.

One of the reasons why we are so susceptible in the Philippines market is that on the whole people do not yet have the capacity to buy fresh milk that has been brought in from overseas. They cannot afford it. That is why the powdered product comes in. The reason why the Americans subsidise the powdered

SPEECH.PARA: product is that their greater distance from the market does not leave them at a disadvantage when product has been processed and powdered because it keeps longer. Obviously, with a fresh product we can effectively, as our citrus producers have found, lock out people who are a long way away. A fresh product is after all a higher quality product because people are getting a product which is purer.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying the Americans have to recognise that their friends are being hurt by their actions. Their friends have a limited tolerance for this sort of activity. I thought it was very peculiar that the Americans were suggesting that defence arrangements be one of the negotiating chips in their trade dispute with Japan. If we took that attitude in this country, I am sure that our American friends would be hopping up and down at the suggestion that we were going to blackmail them. I do not think our friendship should be taken for granted. I do not believe the Australian dairy industry should be taken for granted either.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The dairy produce bills, which are before the Senate at the moment, replace an arrangement that worked very successfully for the dairy industry where it transferred a levy on whole milk of some 1 1/2c a litre to the manufacturing milk sector, which allowed Australia's dairy industry to compete on the international market. It did that very well. The industry is worth $1.4 billion. It is the fourth largest rural export industry in Australia. It has done a magnificent job.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry has rationalised itself over the last 20 years into one of the most efficient industries. Coming from a position of relative weakness in the rural perspective of our primary industry, it has developed into probably one of the most successful, if not in the first three most successful, primary industry. It has rationalised itself in Queensland, where there were thousands of small 40- to 50-acre dairy farms with 20 or 30 cows, into 1,600 very successful primary industry businesses. It has led the way in many instances for primary industry.

The dairy industry now finds that it was not conforming with the new World Trade Organisation. Its leader, who is a very successful industry leader, Mr Pat Rowley, negotiated successfully with the government to get another scheme in which would replace the scheme the dairy industry had, and this is covered by the subsequent legislation. That is the background of why we are bringing this legislation forward.

I too would like to add my concerns to those of my colleague Senator O'Chee, who has said there is concern in primary industry. There is concern all over Australia that the GATT round, and the next step to that is the World Trade Organisation, is starting to go a bit wobbly in the knees. We expected great things from the World Trade Organisation, and Australian primary industry made tremendous sacrifices in the interests of getting the GATT round and the next step, the World Trade Organisation, clarified.

Those sacrifices caused severe pain out in the farmlands where tariffs were cut to the bone and where different schemes were amended because they were not GATT legal. We saw the citrus industry take a huge belt. The tobacco industry had its subsidies and levies cut. We deregulated the wool industry by taking the floor price out. We deregulated the wheat industry by deregulating the domestic price, which lowered the price of wheat in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did away with the sugar embargo.

—Yes, I will come to that, Senator. You might be able to assist me. We deregulated the domestic wheat industry. We removed the sugar embargo. We made huge sacrifices right across the spectrum of primary industry all over Australia in the hope that the rest of the world would follow suit. Now we find that some of our so-called friends are not playing the game.

PARA.TAB: There was a headline in the Australian Financial Review not so long ago which said that subsidies in America had risen instead of fallen and that there were dirty subsidies appearing on farm support. If the Americans want to subsidise their farmers for various reasons—to keep them on the farm because they provide cheap food, or for environmental reasons or for any other reason—good luck to them. That is their right and they should be free to do so. But that is not what is happening now.

What is happening now is that the EEP money is being taken away from the traditional markets. We were told that was there to stop the European Union from taking America's markets. So this was their purpose: to start up this massive export enhancement program and pour millions and billions of dollars into it to protect their markets against the CAP program from the EU.

The EU has sorted itself out, but now America is directing that EEP money into our traditional Asian markets. We have seen America attack the Philippines market of powdered milk and milk products. I do not know where we go. We send Senator McMullan over. He goes over on a pilgrimage. He is followed by Senator Bob Collins. They go over there and continually bow the knee and touch their forelock to the Americans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bill O'Chee is going, too.

—Senator O'Chee is going and I have been. Everyone has been. We all go down the same path, we all get told the same story and nothing ever changes. I think all we are doing is promoting the American tourism industry! We all go over, we all make the pilgrimage and we all get the same answer: `We have to look after our farmers.' We have to look after our farmers, too.

PARA.TAB: This nation has led the world in taking the cuts. Primary industry in Australia has led the farmers around the world. There would not be any sector of Australia's primary industry that has been untouched by deregulation and by cuts in programs. But it is a two-way street. You can go so far and do everything that is possible to get into the World Trade Organisation.

I raised some fears. When we accepted the World Trade Organisation, Australia made tremendous sacrifices in its loss of some of its sovereignty in some of the things we had to accept. For instance, our anti-dumping laws had to be watered down to meet the requirements of the World Trade Organisation. I made that very point at the Senate inquiry where we investigated this. But I was told by the government that that was not so. I was told that I was being an alarmist, a populist and trying to raise the alarm. I see now that Senator Collins and the government agrees with me.

Our anti-dumping policy, which I did not think was all that flash, has been watered down. It is now agreed that it was completely inadequate. I do not know what the government proposed to do about it, but it was another one of the links we took in the interests of the World Trade Organisation.

I hope the dairy industry will continue to develop, grow, export and be one of Australia's main dollar earners. The industry has a tremendous leader in Pat Rowley, who goes out and negotiates with the government but does not apply parliamentary pressure. He does things in a different way from some of the other rural industries, but he generally gets what he asks for, and that makes him a very good leader.

I wanted to make those few remarks because I agree with my colleague Senator O'Chee, whose office is very close to the Malanda Cooperative on the Atherton Tablelands, which is very successful and very big. This world is a two-way street: you give a bit, but you have to get a bit back. Australian farmers have given everything and they have got nothing back.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly in response. Firstly, I would like to thank the coalition for supporting this legislation. I share the concerns, particularly some of the broader trade concerns and the detailed concern about the EEP subsidies for dried milk powder into the Philippines, that have been echoed by Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee. I know my minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), who is in the US at the moment specifically in relation to the issue of subsidies of US agricultural commodities, their effect on US exports and in turn their detrimental effect on our exports, is vigorously taking up these issues.

PARA.TAB: One of the good aspects of the World Trade Organisation is that it gives us a framework of agreement in which to tackle some of those subsidies and see them reduced. Also, it gives us a framework in which to prosecute our claim of unfair treatment in a variety of areas—not just in the dairy industry but in the agricultural industry and other industries generally.

The arrangements that we are considering today are important to the dairy industry. Again, I would agree with the opposition: Pat Rowley is a very effective advocate for the dairy industry. I have met him on a number of occasions.

The dairy industry is a very successful industry. It was only 20 or 30 years ago that it looked like dairy was down and out for good. But now, as Senator Boswell has pointed out, not only has it recovered domestically but also it is one of our great exporters. TALK.START.PARA: —In the 15th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, Super guarantee: its track record, the committee addressed certain aspects of the small amounts problems and put forward a number of recommendations. Since the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge, the overwhelming concern of people contributing small amounts was the problem of the erosion of the capital contribution of the employer by fees and charges, especially for those people who changed jobs frequently or who were on low incomes.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 and cognate bills, which are currently before the Senate, specifically address the small amounts problem. However, I believe it would also be useful to include in this debate the related further issue of the superannuation transfer protocol, which will be introduced not through legislation but through regulation. Therefore, to fully appreciate the total picture of the small accounts issue, I think we have to refer during this debate to both this legislation and the transfer protocol.

As I said earlier, perhaps the greatest criticism of the superannuation guarantee charge surrounds the reduction of small balances by fees and charges. As evidence of the maturity of the industry, it is pleasing to report that the industry has been working with the government to devise further ways of achieving better outcomes for members with small account balances.

In the past members have been faced with difficult administrative procedures in transferring their superannuation benefits, particularly when they change employment. The focus of the interaction with the industry and government has been to find ways to streamline and transfer processes as members change jobs—and I welcome that.

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation sees the lodgment of small amounts with the Taxation Office as an interim or short-term measure—and just how interim is a matter of some question. But the Liberal and National parties perhaps take a harder line, and I am foreshadowing a committee stage amendment of a sunset clause in terms of the role for superannuation of the Taxation Office in handling small amounts. But once the concept of the ATO was introduced in terms of handling small amounts, the industry responded very quickly, and it was perhaps the industry superannuation funds that took the lead in accepting small amounts without reduction of the capital contribution by way of fees and charges.

This process essentially has meant some degree of cross-subsidisation, which is not always welcome but under the circumstances was deemed necessary and desirable. Naturally, other funds have followed some of the leading industry funds in adopting similar processes.

Perhaps the most important bill in this package of bills with which the Senate is dealing is the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill 1995. This establishes a reserve, known as the superannuation holdings account reserve, to facilitate the collection of small amounts by the Taxation Office.

The cost of the establishment of such a reserve will be in the order of $5.6 million, while the annual cost of administration will be between $7 million and $7 1/2 million. Those running costs of between $7 million and $7 1/2 million will be offset by the earnings of the moneys in this reserve fund. But I must point out that there will be no erosion of the capital contributions made to Taxation Office holding accounts where an employer cannot find a fund that will accept small contributions. I must say that it would be fairly difficult for an employer not to find a fund nowadays, but this facility is there that will accept such moneys.

Member protection rules will protect amounts under $1,000, and measures will be in place by 1 July 1995, hence the importance of getting this legislation through before the Senate rises. In fact, funds that decide not to operate under the new rules will not be able to accept small superannuation amounts from new members and, therefore, will be required to transfer existing balances below $1,000 to a fund which will protect employees.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has provided a list of those who provide member protection. For the purpose of this debate, I think it might be useful to incorporate such a list in Hansard. I seek the leave of the Senate to do so.
