TALK.START.PARA: —The arrangements of the reserve will not be a superannuation fund and, therefore, not subject to the costly prudential standards of superannuation funds requiring trustees, et cetera. The reserve will accept both mandated—that is, award—and superannuation guarantee contributions plus voluntary employer contributions, referred to as deposits, on behalf of an employee. Moneys paid into the reserve will be allocated to an account of the employee and will be maintained for that employee's benefit.

PARA.TAB: When the member's account accumulates to a sustainable balance of $1,200, the balance can then be transferred to a complying superannuation fund of the member's choice. This amount will be treated as an employer contribution to that fund and will constitute a taxable contribution of the fund.

Generally, employees will not have direct access to their account balances. However, in order to facilitate and encourage the transfer of accounts that exceed $1,200 to a superannuation fund, interest will not be credited on amounts in excess of $1,200. However, deductions for employer contributions made to the reserve will only be available where those contributions do not exceed $1,200 per employee per year. On the other hand, amounts in excess of $1,200 can still be contributed but without the benefit of an allowable deduction to the employer. The Small Superannuation Accounts Bill therefore provides a legislative framework for employers to make payments to a superannuation holding accounts reserve, instead of making the small superannuation contributions to a superannuation fund.

Those employers most likely to use the relevant reserve account with the Taxation Office are those who employ casual employees or regular part-time people, or those who work intermittently. Essentially, the employer's contribution will remain protected from fees and charges until it grows to a sustainable level of $1,200 that can be transplanted into a compliance superannuation fund.

It is possible for an individual to apply to the commissioner for payment of his account with the reserve, on the grounds that he is suffering severe financial hardship or on the grounds of disability, providing he has retired from employment due to that disability. On the other hand, when an individual attains the age of 65, he may request that the commissioner pay the balance of his account, with a reserve to him. There is no dollar limit on the account balance when the individual has attained the age of 65. Also, when an individual satisfies the commissioner that he or she is no longer resident in Australia, the amount can be transferred out.

Perhaps this is an opportune time to raise an issue that was also raised in the committee's 15th report, which looked into the superannuation guarantee. Firstly, the committee recommended that the tax office's scheme should be limited to those employers unable to find appropriate funds offering member protection or unable to utilise existing employee accounts. Further, we recommended that PAYE forms should be utilised to simplify employers administration of their superannuation guarantee obligations. I trust that the government will pick up this recommendation, although it is not in the bill.

It is also pleasing that the government has accepted the recommendation of appropriate transfer protocols, which will also be in place by 1 July. However, one committee recommendation still has not been addressed; that is, that the government should look at the removal of the contributions tax, particularly from the early contributions. I believe that would also alleviate the small amounts problem. In other words, the government has asked industry to bear a cost, and we think the government should bear a cost in taking away some of the tax, particularly from the initial contributions.

I think we must acknowledge that Australia now has a superannuation system similar to those in other developed countries, but it is unique in a number of ways, given that the payment of the compulsory superannuation is operated through private sector organisations rather than through a central fund of pay as you go basis. There is, therefore, an element of competition.

The Select Committee on Superannuation that I chair undoubtedly received conflicting evidence about the acceptance of the superannuation guarantee system. However, I must say now that the emerging and perhaps dominant view is that the progressiveness of the superannuation guarantee system has been widely accepted. That acceptance is firming over time. The issue now is really to finetune the arrangement. That is important because we have to protect those funds. They are now worth approximately $200 billion and could increase tenfold into the first part of the next century. From a prudential aspect, the biggest challenge at the moment is therefore handling what I believe is the potentially explosive issue of derivatives.

This is a cognate debate encompassing changes to a number of bills. Given the limited time available, it is absolutely impossible to address all the issues. I will look at the more fundamental ones, and I may seek the opportunity to extend the length of my contribution. I have looked at these bills cognately rather than taking 20 minutes on each bill, so I believe that, under the circumstances, that may not be an unreasonable request.

As a consequence of the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill currently before the Senate, it is also necessary to amend a number of other pieces of legislation. These include the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act, the Taxation Administration Act and the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. Firstly, it was necessary to repeal the Superannuation (Rolled-over Benefits) Levy Act 1993, which permitted prescription of the levy of recouping of costs associated with a register of lost members from eligible rollover funds.

This gives you some idea of the complexity of superannuation legislation. This change will bring about so many consequential changes to so many other acts. It is not surprising that we continually hear the story, `There are too many changes to superannuation. We can't understand it; it is just too complicated.' We also hear people say, `The funds aren't performing well enough.'

If we look at another bill in question, which is the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995, we see that the purpose of that bill is to amend four acts dealing with superannuation for Commonwealth civilian sector employees; namely, the Superannuation Act 1992, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act. It also includes some formal amendments to the Parliamentary Contributions Superannuation Act. That means further change and further complication, but it is all in the right direction.

These amendments are important because they will continue to ensure that the process of Commonwealth superannuation arrangements complies with the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act. What we are trying to do is bring all of these various acts and schemes associated with the Commonwealth into line with the basic requirements of what are known as the SIS rules.

Only this week the Australian Retirement Income Streams Association submitted to the committee that perhaps one of the most effective ways of overcoming the problem of small amounts is for employees to be given ownership of their superannuation arrangements through the operation of an account with their chosen public offer fund to which all employer contributions are placed. It also points out that the bias towards industry funds actually runs counter to other areas of government policy where the government has sought to deregulate industries and public utilities and to encourage greater competition, and this has certainly been in line with the Hilmer recommendations.

I introduce this point because I think this is one way of addressing the small account superannuation, but there are other ways of addressing it. One of the other ways of addressing it, as I have just mentioned, was put forward in a submission to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation by the well-informed Australian Retirement Income Streams Association. I acknowledge its pioneering work in terms of the particular products that it has developed for retirement incomes and, particularly, for what I call allocated pensions, which are a very valuable and useful product.

The simple thrust of the submission form ARISA, the Australian Retirement Income Streams Association, was that the current system does not recognise the basic proposition that people should have control over arrangements which they themselves are funding, whether that funding is direct or indirect. So this sort of proposition is, of course, not far from the Liberal Party view, which is that there should be more competition in terms of giving people the same control over their superannuation fund and their right of choice. Certainly, the advance in electronic transmission of funds through the banking system or through Australia Post does provide a very low cost and efficient facility where funds can be dispatched almost instantaneously right across a number of funds from the employer.

I think the coalition took a courageous stand when it decided that rather than making, for example, retirement savings accounts conditional on this legislation, it would leave it as an election issue. It is just so important to get the small amounts in place before 1 July that we really did not want to be seen to be hindering the timing of putting into place what I call the intermediate step of the arrangements of the holding accounts through the Australian Taxation Office system.

The Liberal Party believes there is a role for retirement savings accounts. However, my personal belief is that they are better situated at the bottom end of the spectrum. Once the amount starts to grow, they should be subject to the same prudential guidelines and trustee control that most other superannuation funds are subject to. This is something that I think should be put to the electorate at the next election rather than holding up this important bill, and I commend Mr Connolly for acknowledging this. Mr Connolly is the coalition spokesman on superannuation and is doing a very good job.

We should also look at this question of choice, because choice is inevitably involved in this whole question of superannuation. I must point out to the Senate that there are actually two aspects of choice. Firstly, there is beneficiary or member investment choice, which is allowed under SIS but which must be not only within the investment strategy guidelines laid down by the SIS rules and regulations themselves but also under a strategy determined by the trustees.

Secondly, and quite distinct from the first—people often confuse this point—there is a choice of fund. I issue a warning in relation to the issue of choice of fund. I do not want to see people locked into poorly performing superannuation funds day after day or year after year.

The concept that the government introduced of providing temporary capital gains tax relief for those funds that rollover or merge with each other is indeed welcomed, but what the government must do is extend this exemption from capital gains tax where funds do decide to merge. Over time there will be poorly performing funds and, in some cases, there should be pressure to encourage them to merge.

The big problem is: when should trustees send the message out that there should be a merger. This is always somewhat difficult. Therefore, I think the concept of temporary capital gains tax relief should be extended to a permanent arrangement. I believe we should also extend the scope of the concept. For example, approved deposit funds get an exemption from capital gains tax if they merge into a superannuation fund, but not necessarily if they merge into another ADF.

One of the difficulties at the moment with superannuation funds is the emphasis on what I call short termism which results in fund managers jostling for poll position in terms of quarterly returns. What we must do is develop a long-term reporting process. I would like to see something incorporated in the annual statements. Members really need to know how their funds are performing in the long run in relation to other funds. (Extension of time granted)

There is a suggestion that a long-term or five-year figure produced by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission or the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, which is an umbrella organisation which plays a valuable role in setting the direction for superannuation in this country, could be included in each fund's member reporting mechanism when they are looking at the particular year under review. Members could then see how well their fund is performing compared with the overall average.

There are arguments against this, but people need to look at this issue more realistically than on a short-term basis. People get worried about short-term results in the paper. There have to be mechanisms where members can transfer with minimum cost and inconvenience. There also have to be mechanisms for the transfer or merger of those funds which are, on a long-term basis, consistently under-performing.

With the prolific increase in do-it-yourself super, commonly known as DIY super, it is not surprising that professional fund managers are worried about the outflow of their retail funds to do-it-yourself super. People with some investment knowledge who have been sensible enough to access the necessary technical and outside skills and resources should be able to continue with do-it-yourself super.

I remind the Senate that there are two reasons for this outflow of moneys from the retail sector of super into do-it-yourself super. The reasons are the poor investment returns and the concern of members about fees and charges. The investment manager should be, rather than curtailing the operations of do-it-yourself super, addressing the two issues that I have just spoken about.

Some of the leading superannuation funds are performing quite well. I wish to use the opportunity to acknowledge the role and performance of a number of industry funds that have certainly been quite remarkable in their attempt to both contain costs and maximise returns. This leads me to the whole question of competition. I believe that there are certainly economies of scale. If we tend to encourage too many of these smaller superannuation funds or encourage superannuation to go in particular directions, we may not necessarily be doing what is best in the long term. There are obviously warm fuzzy feelings about certain types of investments in the short term, but they may not necessarily be best in the long term.

In conclusion, this leads me to address the issue of derivatives. The injudicious use of derivatives has the potential to reduce sizeable superannuation investments into small amounts. The Senate committee is pressing the ISC for a quicker response to the establishment of standards to regulate the uncontrolled use of derivatives. I have yet to see evidence of self-regulatory or prudential supervision that gives me sufficient confidence that another Barings type fiasco is less likely to occur in the future than it has in the past.

We are all aware that the rate of change in the investment industry has been absolutely enormous. It was only two months ago that assent was given to the Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill, which facilitates the trade of share ratios on Australian securities and futures exchanges. Products that were unknown 10 years ago are now part of that vocabulary. The issue is how parliament can keep control of these fast-moving changes in the commercial community and the application of these new products to superannuation and the risks that they may involve.

Nevertheless, partly in response to the rate and extent of change in this industry, it is clear that there is a degree of concern and conflicting sentiment as to the balance of utility and security that derivatives afford. It is amongst this debate that I wish to put a special case for superannuation. One of the better performing investment managers, Maple-Brown, does not use derivatives.

Again, my time has run out, so I must conclude now. While the gains that leverage can make for investments are enticing, their potential to lose similar amounts represents, I believe, an unacceptable risk to superannuation funds. Superannuation, arguably more than any other form of investment, is an investment that recipients cannot afford to lose. In this debate on the small accounts issue, I have addressed a wider number of issues. They are all related to the safeguarding and security of an investment that is put away and which is so necessary not only to provide a stable, secure retirement income flow but also to increase national saving. I commend the bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a very good speech on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 that I could deliver at this moment because I have been working on it. However, all kinds of problems have caught up with us this morning, so instead of the Racial Hatred Bill I will attempt to address the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 and the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill 1995 in this place.

PARA.TAB: These superannuation bills implement the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in June 1994 to establish a means of treating small amounts. The government's performance in this area has been tardy. In 1992, the Democrats warned that this would be a problem. Indeed, the problem would have been worse had we not raised the payment threshold from $250 to $450. We still believe that the problem could best be fixed by setting up a national fund for casual and part-time employees. In a sense, the ATO collection mechanism parallels or reflects that preference of the Democrats, but it is a second-best option.

I am surprised and rather disappointed that the ACTU, in representing low income workers, has settled for what we believe to be second best. It seems that, now there are dozens of ACTU bottoms on superannuation fund trustee seats, perhaps the ACTU is not as interested as it should be in the small and part-time worker. It seems that instead it speaks as one in a voice undistinguishable from superannuation funds themselves.

This is a worrying trend, especially as we will soon be in this place debating whether to reduce the disposable income of low income earners in compulsory superannuation contributions. The bill sets up an Australian Taxation Office collection mechanism and a superannuation holding reserve system. The object of the reserve is to allow small amounts to accumulate to such a level—that is, $1,200—that there is a viable account. Then the amount will be moved into a superannuation fund.

Superannuation funds will no longer be able to accept small amounts unless they agree to member protect; that is, agree that their fees cannot exceed the earnings of the fund. This ensures that, after allowing for insurance premiums, individual accounts will not go backwards, but in many cases it means that they will not go forwards. It fails to address the key fundamental problem that superannuation funds are not providing, and probably never will provide, a fair deal for low income workers.

Industry assures us that most funds will agree to member protect and that, as the SGC increases, the need for the tax office system will reduce over time. It may be true that there will be fewer ATO accounts needed in five or 10 years time, but there will still be a significant number, especially if the government fails to get its account consolidation process in place. Not only that, but despite assurances from government, I predict that casual and part-time employment will grow, not decline, in the foreseeable future.
Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am coming to that, Senator Watson. We are not sure that is a final answer either. For that reason, we are unable to support at this stage the coalition amendment to have a sunset clause. For one thing, we do not believe that two years is sufficient time. I believe the government will give some assurance at that point, but in spite of that, I do not believe we will come to a stage in the foreseeable future when we will not need the tax office collection mechanism or some other mechanism.
—Just look at it again in two years time. What's wrong with that?

—Thank you for your assurance, Senator Watson. I will listen to the government if it responds to that interjection by you. The government is encouraging funds to join a transfer protocol which will encourage low cost wholesale transfer of accounts between administrators. Membership of the protocol is not compulsory. Low cost transfer is not compulsory. Data matching is not compulsory. In a way, we are simply crossing our fingers and hoping that funds will willingly pay over small amounts because it is in the best interest of their members. I am a little cynical. I am sure you will forgive me for that.

PARA.TAB: I had intended moving amendments to make these things compulsory. However, the government has assured me that it is prepared to revisit the issue if these things do not come to pass. I do hope that success of the transfer protocol arrangements are redebated in this place in 12 months time and, if moral suasion has failed, then the big stick will need to be used.

The second key failing of the proposed system is the exclusion of other financial institutions which are better suited to dealing with small amounts than the large super funds are. Credit unions, building societies—as I understand it—and even perhaps banks have, to varying degrees, signalled a willingness to set up savings accounts which would allow the funds to accumulate with zero or no fees and with small interest. This offer is superior to anything offered yet by a super fund. A payment of even five per cent interest with no fees is better than a guarantee of zero return offered by member protection.

The Democrats do not believe that it is appropriate in this debate to discuss whether banks or other institutions should generally have access to superannuation. We have not been persuaded that this is the issue of competitive neutrality that the banks claim it is. However, we have been persuaded, based on representations from the credit union sector, that the financial institutions can offer a useful product to help low income earners and can provide a fairer deal for low income earners than that provided by the super funds.

The Senate select committee set a series of criteria for a product in super savings accounts which we believed would be useful. The criteria are: no fees; an interest rate broadly comparable with term deposits—currently about five per cent or six per cent; access to the super complaints tribunal for complaints; and that funds be transferred to an aggregated fund when the amount of $3,000 is reached. The credit union sector has welcomed these conditions. I will be tabling later in this session a private member's bill to propose such a product.

The final issue I want to talk about is the ATO mechanism, as it is still failing to provide what we believe would be a fair deal for low income earners. First, the earnings will be restricted to government and other trust account investments. In the long-term, this will reduce earnings by about one to two per cent in real terms. Second, the full running costs of the reserve will be deducted from earnings.

In my view, this is unfair. Low income earners get little benefit from superannuation concessions. Of the $6 billion of super concessions, over a third flow to the six per cent of people earning $50,000 or more per year, while the 22 per cent earning $20,000 or less get just 3.3 per cent of that tax benefit. Surely the government could find $7 million in this massively regressive super system to help the lowest paid even up the score a little. Its failure to do so shows that it and the ACTU are just not interested in low income earners and the battlers.

Third, the government intends taxing contributions and earnings at the full 15 per cent, yet private super funds, due to imputation credits, can get away with a tax rate of 10.5 per cent. So high income earners will be lower taxed on their higher super earnings than low income earners. The government has been very clever here. It ensures that it gets its running costs paid before tax, and then it taxes what is left. The ATO is guaranteed a good stream of money. The Democrats would prefer to see the tax rate set at the tax rate prevailing for private super funds, which is currently about 15 per cent.

Fourth, the government will not allow award super to be paid into the ATO. This means that it will still be possible for a worker who is under several awards or industrial agreements to hold several active accounts. The government assures us that the industry funds are the most advanced on the transfer protocol, but this only covers inactive accounts. It is totally silent on active accounts, which is the area that the ATO is supposed to fix.

The Democrats had intended moving a large number of amendments to this bill. The early debate of this bill, and the refusal of the government and the opposition to join with us to make this system more effective, precludes us from doing so. With great reluctance, I will support this bill as it is better than nothing, but it is nowhere near the fair deal it could have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) basically works on the adjustment of the Commonwealth super scheme for its own employees, the old Commonwealth superannuation scheme, and the newer public sector superannuation scheme. As far as I can make out, the changes are simply part of the ongoing adjustment of superannuation which is required under law for schemes to maintain their position under changing legal regimes. It also seeks to make the position of part-time workers more explicit, although it does so by regulation rather than through legislation. There are a number of other minor technical changes, including the elimination of sexist language.

PARA.TAB: We do not see any problems with this bill, which is mainly technical change and correction at this time. We do, however, have problems in relation to the future of superannuation. The Superannuation Laws Amendment (Small Accounts and Other Measures) Bill is a further substantive change to the super scheme. It is designed to address the problems that have been created for part-time and casual workers by compulsory employer superannuation. The problem is that when these workers have small sums paid into numerous different funds the money simply disappears, eaten up by charges. Obviously, in such a circumstance these workers get nothing from such measures. It would be better for them to get wages which are traded off against punitive gains such as super contributions.

The Greens (WA) basically support the scheme. We do not believe anyone could fail to support the principle of a scheme that tries to ensure that there are at least no losses from superannuation payments, especially for the poorest workers. We do feel, however, there is still progress to be made on the issue, but this is a corrective step. Whether it is a step in the right direction raises the whole issue of the relative merits of national savings schemes, private superannuation or simply paying workers and letting them deal with their own situation. But within the superannuation environment this measure at least is progress.

The essence of the scheme is that the employer super contribution will be made into an eligible fund nominated by the employer. If it is currently being funded into a fund which is not an eligible fund, the non-eligible fund must transfer the account to an eligible fund without charging exit fees. When casual workers have an amount of money under $1,000 in an eligible fund and are employed by a new employer, they must state there is money in their fund and have it transferred again without exit fees to the funds into which contributions are currently being paid. I am not sure what happens if a worker has more than one job and is getting money paid into two funds simultaneously. Perhaps the minister can expand on that. An alternative is that the employer can nominate to put funds into the Australian Taxation Office fund that will be set up. This will hold super contributions until they reach $1,200, at which time it is intended they may be transferred to an eligible fund.

What do these funds do? They offer protection from having the contributions eaten away. Fifteen per cent of the contributions are taken in tax in any case. Funds and the tax office will pay interest if any money is left after fees are taken out. Both eligible funds and the tax office will not be able to charge fees in excess of the interest earned. The impact is likely to be that no benefit actually accrues, no money is made—the money just sits there. This is better than having it disappear but not a lot better. It is certainly not as good as having the money where it can be used or where it might generate enough interest to keep up with inflation.

Some people have mentioned that the Australian tax office is more likely to generate some real return than superannuation funds. Whether or not that is true, one advantage of many private funds is that they offer life and disability insurance to their members. So there are some real advantages in being in some private super funds even where no interest is made on money.

However, the Greens (WA) have a few major points to make about the Australian tax office reserve scheme. The first is that while, initially, the scheme will invest money effectively in only government bonds there is the possibility that, through the financial management and accountability measures, investments may be made elsewhere with the potential that the money could be used more explicitly to pursue government programs, even though bonds are essentially used in this way. The measure then makes it possible to create a pool of funds for government purposes outside the normal budgetary process of appropriations. Perhaps the government would like to respond as to whether that is ever likely to be the case.

A second aspect is that there is the possibility that this bill, in establishing mechanisms for the Australian Taxation Office to deal directly with superannuation funds, may be used to facilitate the budget superannuation scheme of employee and government contributions. We are assured that Treasury and the Australian tax office would prefer not to have to deal with superannuation. The government has rejected notional savings, or superannuation schemes, in favour of private sector superannuation in spite of the plethora of regulations that are required to protect people required by law to be involved in superannuation as a savings and investment vehicle. I am still concerned that while the opportunities are there they may be acted upon. I do not feel we have enough time to ensure that this is not an implication of this bill.

The government may think that a small party such as ours has many teams and that we can operate on each bill for months at a time. That is not the case. An amendment was circulated by Senator Watson today and I asked if it was possible for us to have the time to deal with that amendment—for the chamber to go on to the next second reading debate in order for us to be able to deal with that amendment and to assess its implications. The government said, `No, it's been around for a long time.'

Even though we have not seen the amendment before, there was an amendment in the lower house. We are not in the lower house, and we do not get presented with copies of lower house amendments. Therefore, I find it a bit rich for the government to say, `You should've known it was in the lower house. Therefore, you should know everything about each bill before it comes even if it is not circulated to the Senate.' In terms of process, I think the public would be very disappointed to know that this is what the government thinks is the proper way to deal with legislation which is going to affect their future. This is what the government thinks is a good and proper way to deal with legislation.

In spite of the obvious benefits of the act for people in broken unemployment, or underemployment, there are attractions in the opposition's amendments. I will say, however, that they would have been much more attractive if the sunset clause had been only for the Australian tax office's involvement rather than for the entire bill. As it is, a sunset clause on the act would probably on balance do more damage than good. I will be happy to hear the arguments presented by Senator Watson when that time comes around.

While this bill is a substantial improvement, the concerns persist and it really does not solve a number of the problems that we see associated with superannuation. I would like some commitment from the government that there will be a democratic process and that this Senate will be part of the democratic process, and that when the government's budget superannuation comes into being it will be a matter whereby the concerns of the public will be debated fully and properly. There will need to be some legislative mechanism, and perhaps the government could tell us when that might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak reasonably briefly on these superannuation bills before the Senate today. I particularly want to speak in relation to the bill which deals with the small amounts problem and the government's attempt to solve that problem. The superannuation committee, which I have been a member of almost since my time of coming into this Senate three years ago, has been made aware of the problem of small amounts for a very long time. It seems as though the government itself has taken a long time to address that problem, which we know has been around for a long time.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say also that the work of that committee under the chairmanship of Senator Watson, who has been on the committee since its inception—and I know that Senator Sherry was the initial chairman of that committee—has been recognised for a long time. There is a tremendous amount of goodwill on that committee in making sure that, when we report, the recommendations we put forward are in the best interests of all Australians, particularly in the area of superannuation. That area is an ongoing problem throughout the community, particularly in relation to the community's awareness, understanding and education. Certainly in that area there is a lot more work to be done.

I also come to the committee having spent seven years prior to my entry into this place working in the superannuation industry. Even before I came to this place I was made acutely aware, because I was dealing with some of the clients involved, of the problem that fees and charges were having on small amounts and the abundance of small amounts that each member had purely because of the direction of where their superannuation contributions had to go. Over a long period of time now we have had a vast array of submissions about the problems of small amounts. The government has been rather tardy in at least helping to solve those problems that exist.

The need for addressing the small amounts problem is exacerbated by the government's overall attitude and philosophy towards the universality of coverage for superannuation. I know that in the eyes of most of the population there is a need for a universality of coverage. But it is taking it too far when that goes down to a contribution being made on the first dollar earned, particularly when at the end of the day the people who are having these very small amounts contributed on their behalf will receive little or no benefit when it comes to their retirement and any income that they may receive in retirement. Throughout my period in the superannuation industry that was one of the areas of concern that was always raised by people who were compelled to pay small amounts into funds which, at that stage, were charging quite outrageous fees and charges. I am the first to admit that.

This issue also brings us to the debate regarding the threshold, which is part of the problem with small amounts. We have had hundreds of submissions presenting various points of view to the committee. There has been a wide range of submissions from Eva Cox of the women's economic think-tank, who could hardly be called an economic rationalist, to other employers who have put the same point of view suggesting that the threshold should be raised so that people at the end of day are likely to be able to provide in some way towards their own retirement—although we know that many people will be on a public and part private stream for a long time in the future. We get a broad range of advice that we should be looking at increasing the threshold. That is one area the government has failed to address and should address.

In the 15th report of the Senate select committee one of the first elements in the proposal to alleviate the small amounts problem is for consideration to be given to changing the SGC threshold from $450 a month to a quarterly amount. This would mean that people in seasonal work may be able to avoid the problems being caused by having very small amounts put into a vast array of accounts from a variety of employers. I am doubtful whether the legislation put forward today will overcome that in any way.

The other major issue I want to address which would alleviate many of the problems associated with small accounts is the adoption of member choice. If we could have member choice of funds it would mean that those people who have several employers could be sure that all of the contributions for the work that they do could be directed towards the one fund. If that were the case, it would eliminate a number of the small accounts. In these days of modern technology, with computerisation, where we can do a range of other things by transferring money electronically into a variety of accounts, if our money can be put into our bank accounts at the end of the month electronically, I am sure there is a possibility the same thing can be done with superannuation contributions.

If we can introduce member choice of funds, which is another issue that this government has not addressed, it would eliminate the need for so many small accounts being placed in another facility—whether it be the tax office, small superannuation accounts, credit unions or any other organisations. We had submissions that Australia Post now has the facility to handle small amounts and superannuation accounts. It was very enlightening evidence.

Once member choice is introduced—as I have said, it can only get easier in the future with the use of technology—then the problems confronting those people who have a variety of casual jobs and a variety of employers who currently insist that the contributions go into a range of different funds, each with small amounts, could be overcome. Once again, a number of those employees who have small accounts would find that they have much larger accounts which would be manageable by some of the industry funds.

The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations believes that consumer choice should be at the heart of the government's superannuation policy. Allowing small amounts to be placed only with the tax office is hardly allowing consumer choice. A lack of choice is identified by the Federation of Consumer Organisations as the contributing factor to the small amounts problem. Being able to choose a fund that best suits an employee's needs and having the option of amalgamating multiple accounts would result in a single account that they could carry with them throughout their working career.

I am quite sure that, if we get to the stage where the government adopts as part of its policy the situation where members own their own account, can watch their own account and have only one fund to check at any one time, then this government would be getting to the stage where the small amounts problem and all of the associated worries would be alleviated far more than facilitating payments being made to the tax office. Quite frankly, a lot of people in the community do not agree that the tax office is the best place for their money to be put. People are somewhat suspicious of the tax office. I guess that is just a natural happening amongst members of our community. Given a choice between the tax office, a credit union or a small savings superannuation account, I am sure that many people would choose not to use the tax office.

However, that is the way the government has chosen to go in this particular legislation. As an opposition, we agree that we will support that move purely because, if we do not address the problem of small amonts right now and we do not have a facility for the payment of money, the general public and those who are involved in superannuation at what I would call the fringe level—that is, those with very small amounts—are going to become more disenchanted with superannuation than they are at present. When we see what has happened with investments, with the performance and erosion of funds due to fees and charges, there certainly is in the community a lack of confidence as to whether superannuation is ever going to provide people with benefits in their retirement.

The important thing that we have to try to convince the community of is that we are talking about a retirement incomes policy; we are not talking about a superannuation policy. A retirement incomes policy is the only thing that we really ought to be concentrating on. As I said, we will be supporting the government's move to use the tax office, although somewhat reluctantly. I think there are other ways of addressing the problem. People should have a choice between using the tax office and using another vehicle. But the problem has to be addressed today or as soon as possible so that we can help put some confidence back into the superannuation system.

Let us hope that in the near future we will see the government move in the other areas, particularly the area of member choice. Once we can introduce some member choice, I think a lot of the problems with small amounts that we have today will be alleviated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank the various speakers for their contributions in this debate on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1), the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill and the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Small Accounts and Other Measures) Bill. Whilst I did not agree with all his points, Senator Watson, as always, made a very effective and comprehensive contribution. Senator Watson is the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. As has been mentioned in this debate, I preceded him in that position.

PARA.TAB: The range of measures before us today is a cohesive package to deal with what has been known for some time as the problem of small amounts. The measures before us do effectively deal with this problem. They include: member protection of smaller superannuation accounts; reducing the number of multiple accounts; the superannuation holding accounts reserve, which is established by two of the three bills we are considering today; and a range of other initiatives, including measures contained in the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Small Accounts and Other Measures) Bill. They form a cohesive whole and for reasons I will outline a little later, we cannot accept the amendment of the opposition that would remove one of those elements—the superannuation holding accounts reserve—by scrapping it at the end of two years with no effective ongoing process in train.
Before I go on to that issue, I will deal with a couple of matters that Senator Woodley asked and some matters that Senator Chamarette raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Margetts.

—Margetts, sorry. I will deal with Senator Woodley first. The government will not tax the amounts in the superannuation holding accounts reserve. When transferred to a super fund, it becomes a taxable contribution of that fund and is taxed at the fund's rate, normally 15 per cent, less the imputation credits.

PARA.TAB: We, like Senator Watson, do welcome the industry's initiatives in setting up the transfer protocol. The government agrees to report to the parliament on industry progress with the transfer protocol by the last day in September 1996.

In respect of the sunset clause that Senator Watson raised, the government wants funds to do the right thing and to member protect. But we do need the superannuation holding accounts reserve to ensure a complete solution to the small amounts problem. For that albeit diminishing problem—we expect it will be less and less of a problem over time—we need the continuance of that holding accounts reserve beyond two years. To simply have a sunset clause to abolish the holding accounts reserve at the end of two years without knowing what would replace it, would remove one of the effective parts of the package we are presenting to the chamber today.

What would become of moneys in those accounts? We do not know. What would happen to this holding accounts reserve? Would it be subcontracted to someone in the private sector? We do not believe an appropriate way to deal with the holding accounts reserve is to simply have it guillotined out of existence at the end of two years. That is not a responsible way to deal with moneys that are in that holding accounts reserve.

Another issue raised is that of a person who has two jobs—part time, casual or full time—and is in two funds. If you hold two jobs, you will have moneys contributed to two funds, although there are some exceptions. For example, in the hospitality industry—and I was a trustee of the hospitality industry fund—you could work at a hotel and a restaurant in the same city, and so have two employers but, because the fund covers the hospitality industry, it is highly likely that you have moneys going from two employers into the one fund. You would more than likely be charged only one administration charge in those circumstances by the fund, but there are some exceptions. So just because you have two different jobs, particularly in the same industry, does not mean that you are in two different funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but what about the ones who are?

—I am just about to get to that. Let us assume that you are in two, three or four different funds—and that is possible, particularly if you are a part-time or casual employee. If you have moneys going into different funds, by the nature of your employment it is likely that you move from job to job. Casual and part-time employment tends to be more transient than full-time. When you leave a job, you are able to transfer the money over from that fund or those two or three funds and consolidate it.

PARA.TAB: I think one of the unfortunate things is that a lot of people are not aware of their ability to transfer and consolidate their money on leaving a job. The consolidation issue and protection of small amounts in those circumstances, if a person does not consolidate through lack of awareness of consolidation, is dealt with by the member protection of small superannuation accounts. We have recognised that particular problem.

The general issue of small amounts will become less of a problem over time. Most funds charge a flat fee, which is usually between 60c and a dollar a week. That fee does not increase as the contributions increase. At the moment employer contributions are either four or five per cent, depending on the employer's payroll; that rises to nine per cent under the superannuation guarantee. With the recent announcements in the budget, there will be a further six per cent, taking the contributions going into the fund or funds to a total of 15 per cent.

The administration charge does not rise as the contributions rise. So the administration charge as a proportion of contributions—anywhere between 50c and a dollar a week—will decline over time, and the problem of small amounts will decline over time. But there will still be a problem with small amounts, albeit less of a problem over time. That is what this package of measures is designed to deal with.

Senator Margetts has also raised the issue of investment. We have indicated that the moneys will be invested in government bonds—securities of that nature. This government has no intention of investing the moneys in broader forms of investment—that is, in what may concern you as being of a more speculative nature. If it did, I am advised that the Senate could disallow any attempt to do so. We would obviously debate that issue, but the Senate would have the power to disallow any broader form of investment through regulation in this place.

On the budget announcement of the additional six per cent, there will need to be some legislation. I cannot give you the date on which that will be presented to the Senate, but there will have to be legislation at some time in the future. Therefore, the Senate will have an opportunity to debate this, just as we have debated very regularly over the last five or six years superannuation and the specific provisions as they have changed over time.

I am also able to indicate for the record that, whilst we will not accept Senator Watson's amendment which is to do away with the holding accounts reserve automatically at the end of two years, we are willing to accept—and I am not sure in what form it will be—and agree to a review of the operation of the holding accounts reserve and a report back obviously to the Senate, and I am sure that would be back to the House of Representatives as well, within that two year period. I think they are the issues that have been raised in the debate. I thank the senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: SMALL SUPERANNUATION ACCOUNTS BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an issue that I raised at one of the committee hearings with the tax office. I am not sure what part of the bill will overcome the problem that I want to address. The situation is that a casual employee has three or four employers, and the amounts that are due to be paid into superannuation are so small that he chooses to pay them into the holding account at the tax office. Over a period of time, the amount from those four different employers builds up to $1,200. He can either leave it there, attracting no interest, or he can take that $1,200 out and put it into one of the four funds that he would have a choice of because the amount is up to $1,200. He would then have to proceed with the remaining three employers to start all over again with the tax office until he builds another amount up to $1,200. Can you clarify that position? Am I presenting it incorrectly?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the moneys going into the holding account, there are no charges up to $1,200. If the tax office notifies the individual that there is now $1,200 in his account, the individual can choose any one of a number of funds to put the money into, provided he is legally able to access that fund. It could be that he transfers the $1,200 over to one of the three or four industry funds he can access. I think, in those circumstances, it is likely that the employee would go to the two, three or four employers—if he is still employed by them—and ask them to pay the money into the fund that he has directed the money should go to. I am also advised that, under the transfer protocol, if the employee decides it should go into X fund, any further moneys going into the superannuation holding account from the employers will automatically flow over. It will not be held in the holding reserve account.

—I am aware that there are no charges up to $1,200; that was not the problem. Employees have certain funds that they direct their employers to pay into, which happens in various cases. Once the amount gets to $1,200 and the employee is notified and withdraws the money and puts it into a fund—regardless of what that fund is—are you saying that, if the employers from the other casual jobs wish to continue paying, they can continue to pay into the tax office and the tax office will automatically transfer that money to the existing fund?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us understand that the three or four employers are putting the money into the holding accounts reserve because there may not be a particular industry fund covering their particular industry. Their industry may not have a fund for a particular reason, whether it is to do with the industrial award or the particular nature of the employment. Therefore, I think the employee, upon having knowledge of a fund that the money should go to, would go back to those employers and ask them to pay the money into the particular fund that he or she has nominated. I think that is the likely scenario.

PARA.TAB: If the employer did not, the employee would certainly have to notify the tax office to pay the money into that particular fund. They may not, but it would be silly not to. If they have chosen fund X and they still have money going into the superannuation holding account reserve, they would be silly not to notify the tax office to transfer the money over.

The transfer protocol also provides for an automatic payment over to that particular fund. If three or four employers keep putting the money into the holding reserve for the tax office, the transfer protocol then allows for that money over and above the $1,200 to be transferred into the employee's X fund. The transfer protocol allows the money to move automatically out of the tax office fund into that fund X.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put to you, Senator Sherry, that in effect you are giving that person member choice, which is not available to many other people who are involved in industry funds. You are allowing member choice for some people, but you are not allowing it for others. That really is the basis of the argument that I put in the second reading debate. If you allow member choice, you eliminate half of these problems. In effect, you are actually providing member choice for some people who have a variety of small accounts, and you are not allowing people who are in other industry funds to have that same choice.

—The scenario that I have heard from people down south who are involved with the wine industry or the fruit industry is that it is a nightmare for the employers to deal with different funds. So you are saying that money can be required to be transferred once a person has $1,200. If people are dealing with several different employers, it would be a nightmare for small business operators to have to then not only be involved with the ATO but also be required or directed by their employees to continue putting individual amounts into their other superannuation funds. Whilst you are answering Senator Ferguson's question, could you tell me whether you have talked to small businesses like orchardists and so on to find out what the implications are and whether or not they can do this?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the principles you raise, Senator Margetts, in fact, rebuts Senator Ferguson's general theme of member choice—the so-called freedom of choice. If, say, 10 employees in a small business were to exercise freedom of choice and determine which fund their superannuation is to be paid into—and I frankly think it is more the employer who would do that rather than the employee—
—You said they could do it.

—No, I did not. I will get to your point in a moment. I am just rebutting this general issue of freedom of choice and the point you make about small business. If 10 employees want the money paid into their individual superannuation fund, wherever it may be, it would be chaotic for an employer to have to pay into 10 different funds. That is why I disagree with the general theme put by Senator Ferguson.

PARA.TAB: If there are three or four employers paying into the superannuation holding accounts reserve, when the amount reaches $1,200 the employee can have that money passed over to another fund if he or she wishes. Only the employee can require the payment of future moneys out of the superannuation holding accounts reserve. Therefore, if those three or four employers are putting money into the superannuation holding accounts reserve that will continue. In relation to the employee who had the $1,200 put into fund X, the superannuation holding accounts reserve, along with the transfer protocol, will then transfer any future collections of money to the fund that the employee has nominated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is member choice.

—We have to agree to disagree on your concept of member choice. The small employers are still paying into the superannuation holding accounts reserve. It is then that the money is passed over to another fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense my colleague Senator Ferguson is right. When you look at the legislation in relation to the holding accounts reserve plus the protocol you find that there is choice as to which fund the person who has the entitlements can put those funds into. However, if subsequently that person works in an industry that has an industry fund, under the arrangements at the present time, those funds do not go into the reserve account they go into the particular industry fund. SPEECH.PARA: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1995

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 proposes to amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the rate of Medicare levy from 1.4% to 1.5% for the 1995-96 and later income years. The Bill will also increase the low income thresholds below which people will not be required to pay any levy and increase the upper thresholds for which special phasing-in rules apply.

Mr President, Medicare levy receipts as a proportion of Medicare outlays have fallen from over 30 per cent in 1988-89 to an expected to 24 per cent in 1994-95. The adjustment to the rate will ensure that Medicare levy receipts make a greater contribution to the cost of government health programs.

The benefit to revenue of the increase in the Medicare levy is estimated to be $230 million in 1995-96, $240 million in 1996-97, $260 million in 1997-98 and $280 million 1998-99. The estimated cost of raising the low income thresholds will be $10 million in each of the years 1995-96, 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99.

The Bill also makes a minor technical amendment to the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the upper limit threshold for trustees of a trust estate for the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years. There is no cost to revenue of these changes.

The Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995 will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax in line with the change from 1.4% to 1.5% in the Medicare levy rate commencing from 1 July 1995. However, to avoid two different rates in the 1995-96 FBT year of tax the rate to apply to the year commencing 1 April 1995 is to be a composite rate of 48.475%. From 1 April 1996 and all later FBT years the rate will be increased to 48.5%.
The benefit to the revenue of the increase in the rate is estimated to be $5 million in each of the FBT tax years 1995-96, 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to Honourable Senators.
I commend the bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY BILL

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on jet aircraft landings at airports where noise amelioration programs are being funded by the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable Senators will be aware that construction of a new parallel runway at Sydney Airport was completed during 1994 and the runway came into operation in November 1994.

When the recently installed air traffic control system is operating at full capacity, the traffic handling capacity of the new runway configuration will be about 80 aircraft movements per hour compared with 55 movements per hour prior to the commissioning of the new runway.

While the operation of the new parallel runway configuration significantly reduces the overall number of people seriously affected by aircraft noise, particularly those to the east and west of the Airport, it significantly increases the level of noise exposure for residents of some other areas mainly to the north of the airport.

Recognising that this would be the case, the Government in 1991 commissioned a Steering Committee, convened by the Federal Airports Corporation, to prepare a Noise Management Plan for Sydney Airport identifying possible measures to mitigate the noise impact of the new runway operation. A Draft Noise Management Plan was subsequently developed with extensive involvement by the three levels of government, the community and the airline industry. The Draft Plan was released for public comment in June 1994.

After considering measures proposed in the Draft Noise Management Plan, the Government announced late last year that it would undertake a major program of acquisition and acoustic insulation of certain buildings in the areas worst affected by noise from the operation of the Airport.

In addition, the Government has initiated a range of other measures, including mandatory flightpaths, take-off procedures for jet aircraft and tighter curfew arrangements to minimise the number of people affected by aircraft noise.

The acquisition and insulation program encompasses voluntary acquisition of up to 113 residential properties within the 40 Australian Noise Exposure Forecast (ANEF) zone; sound insulation of some 4,200 residential properties within the 30 ANEF zone; and sound insulation of schools and colleges, child care facilities, hospitals and health care facilities and churches within the 25 ANEF zone.
The scope of eligibility for this program is at least equal to that of any major overseas airport where a noise amelioration program is in place.
It is the Government's intention that the announced program be completed within a three year period. This again compares favourably with the rate of implementation of overseas programs.

Based on indicative cost data developed in conjunction with the Draft Noise Management Plan, the cost of the program was originally estimated at some $183 million. Following a re-assessment of eligible buildings and the scope and cost of required works, the estimated overall cost of the program is now $260 million (in 1995-96 prices).
The airlines and their passengers will be the beneficiaries of the increased runway capacity created at Sydney Airport.
It follows that they should be required to meet the cost of reducing the noise impacts on the affected communities in the vicinity of the Airport.
The levy which this bill seeks to impose will provide the means for giving effect to this principle.
The bill provides that the levy will apply only at declared airports, which are those where the following conditions apply

PARA.TAB: there are residences or public buildings in noise affected areas (as defined by ANEF contours) around
the Airport
there is or has been a Federal Government funded airport noise amelioration program in place
and the amount of levy collected at a given time is not in excess of the costs to the Federal Government of that noise amelioration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The levy will apply in the first instance to Sydney Airport only. This recognises the very significant change in noise patterns around the airport which results from the opening of the new runway.

The Government would similarly expect that, where new runway developments or extensions enabling a significant change in either the number or type of jet aircraft usage occur at other major airports, the need for a noise amelioration program will also arise.

Honourable Senators will be aware that the Government has embarked on a program of leasing Federal airports. As part of the next stage of the disposal process, the Government will examine how best to ensure responsible environmental behaviour by users and operators of leased airports.

Prospective airport operators will clearly have an interest in the development of environmental management measures, including noise amelioration, which may be warranted by significant runway works and changes in operations at the airports they will be leasing.
These issues will therefore be addressed in the context of the airport leasing program which will see the first of our major Federal airports leased in 1996.
Turning to the levy itself, the amount of levy payable per jet aircraft landing will be determined according to a formula developed as part of the Sydney Airport Draft Noise Management Plan.

The formula provides that the noisier an aircraft the higher will be the rate of levy payable per landing. For example, the amount of levy payable for a landing by a B747 will be some three to four times higher than for a B737 depending on the specific noise characteristics of the particular aircraft.

The bill provides for the levy to apply to landings by jet aircraft only. This reflects the fact that generally jet aircraft create greater noise disturbance than propeller driven aircraft. There will be some quieter small jet aircraft which are not liable for the levy.
It is a requirement of the bill that revenue from the levy at a particular declared airport not exceed the cost of the noise amelioration program at that airport.
To spread the cost impact on airlines, it is not envisaged that the levy will necessarily be raised at a rate which keeps pace with spending on a noise amelioration program.

The levy rate will be prescribed by regulation subject to the limitations established in the bill. It is proposed that there will be automatic annual adjustments of the levy rates in line with Consumer Price Index movements.

The rate will also be periodically reviewed in the light of other parameters such as growth rates in jet aircraft landings and the costs of noise amelioration programs that might be established at any other airports.

It is the Government's intention that the rate of levy be initially set at an amount of $155 per noise unit. This rate will be adjusted as necessary so as to enable the cost of the Sydney Airport Noise Amelioration Program to be recovered over a period of up to ten years.
In 1995/96, it is expected that the levy will raise some $32.2 million. This translates to an average cost per jet aircraft passenger landing at Sydney Airport of around $3.40.

Mr President, this is a landmark bill. It establishes a regime for recovering from aviation operators the costs of redressing the adverse impact of aircraft noise imposed on communities in the vicinity of airports—immediately in the case of Sydney Airport and at other Australian airports in future years.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY COLLECTION BILL

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to establish a collection regime for the levy imposed by the complementary Aircraft Noise Levy Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill specifies in detail by whom, in what circumstances, and when and how the levy is payable.
It also covers penalty and enforcement arrangements.

The bill provides the necessary powers to allow the levy to be collected by a Commonwealth authority. It is proposed that the Civil Aviation Authority, or Air Services Australia when it is established, will perform this role.

Since the processes for collection of the noise levy readily dovetail with the Authority's own revenue collection activities which are based on aircraft landings, it is expected that this arrangement will minimise administrative costs associated with the collection of the levy.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
