TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills, which we are now commencing debate on at long last, are an integral part of the government's spending proposals for 1995-96. They are usually regarded as the traditional budget bills, even though they appropriate only some 30 per cent of the money that the government will spend during the next financial year. The remainder of the money is appropriated through other acts such as the Social Security Act, to name but one.

PARA.TAB: I want to speak today about the setting of the 1995-96 budget as a whole, its propriety and its relevance to the economic and social needs of our nation and our people. On all three grounds this budget, I would have to say, fails miserably.

This budget is entirely inappropriate to the needs of Australia today. It is a budget based on broken promises, tax lies and deceit. It is a high taxing budget. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now become one of Australia's highest taxing prime ministers. He holds the undisputed record as the Prime Minister who has broken more promises than any other Prime Minister in our history. Some record! This Prime Minister simply cannot be trusted in anything that he says. His record, particularly in the field of taxation, bears eloquent testimony to that.

This budget imposes savage tax increases on business and consumers. It makes it more difficult for business to employ more people. It reduces the available incomes of every Australian. It contains the seeds of inflationary pressures and of interest rate rises. It sells off two prize pieces of the family silver—namely, 50 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas Airways—simply to pay for the government's groceries, its day-to-day expenses, rather than to pay off the enormous debt that this government has accumulated, a debt that has risen in the last four to five years alone from $30 billion to a figure in the order of $100 billion.

The budget does nothing to address our crisis level deficit in our external accounts. It makes the closing of that gaping hole all the more difficult because it has made it even more difficult for our producers of goods and services to be as internationally competitive as they need to be if our living standards are to increase.

The budget has guaranteed that we will rack up increasing amounts of foreign debt and other liabilities and thus reduce our sovereignty and true national independence. There is no surer way of reducing one's national sovereignty than to put our country increasingly in hock to the rest of the world.

This is the budget of a deceitful and incompetent government of economic failure and broken promises. The budget itself is built on very dubious forecasts. In particular, the forecasts for the growth in the national product of 3 3/4per cent during 1995-96 is a figure that must be taken with an increasingly large grain of salt. There is clear evidence, in talking with businesses and business associations and their members, that the business climate appears to have weakened sharply in recent weeks. The 3 3/4per cent forecast could well prove to be optimistic, and the implications of that for jobs is of great concern. Even at a growth of 3 3/4per cent next year, an insufficient number of jobs would be created to meet the growth in the available work force.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that the Prime Minister, at the time of his One Nation statement, said that Australia needed 4 1/2 per cent annual growth to provide the necessary number of jobs to at least start to make a hole in the unemployment figures and to provide the necessary jobs for those coming newly into the work force. In the Treasury estimates the other day, the Treasury officers started to walk away from that commitment. They now seem to be saying that we can possibly get the necessary job growth to achieve a sustainable reduction in the level of unemployment with a figure perhaps of the order of 3 3/4 per cent—that is the one forecast in the budget. But the Treasury officers produced no hard evidence or data at all to support that backflip. It would be a major backflip from the Prime Minister's earlier One Nation statement if the government were to start down that tack.

The budget is built on broken promises. It is financed to an important extent by the Prime Minister's broken promise to provide significant tax cuts to every Australian on 1 January 1996. Remember that that tax cut was enshrined in legislation before the 1993 federal election. I am sure everyone remembers how the Prime Minister said that those tax cuts were l-a-w—law. Equally, people will remember how he attempted to ridicule those who questioned his commitment to those 1 January 1996 tax cut promises.

As we have all known for some time, it has now been confirmed in this budget that what was l-a-w has turned out not to be l-a-w but l-i-e. Those tax cuts have gone. Technically, the government says that they have been deferred and are going to be switched into a contribution towards superannuation for employees. But even if we accept that as a proposition, those tax cuts have been deferred for up to 45 years or more—up to 45 years or more—by the introduction of a compulsory employee superannuation levy to be matched in a few years time by government contributions.

Whilst we would all agree that the encouragement of superannuation is desirable, it should not be achieved by the flagrant, blatant and cynical breaking of tax cut promises solemnly given on the eve of an election, as was the case with this duplicitous government prior to the 1993 election. If l-a-w is law, it should be honoured. The respect for and the integrity of the government of the day should not be shattered by broken promises by transforming l-a-w into l-i-e in the way that this government does as a matter of routine.

The government should also heed the warning, in the context of its savings proposals, of one of the architects of its savings policies, Dr Vince Fitzgerald: without new incentives to save—and there are none in this budget—then workers will merely reduce other forms of savings to meet the new compulsory superannuation levy on them.

It must also be pointed out that the government's new compulsory savings arrangements will do nothing at all to assist or in any way benefit large sections of the community, particularly self-funded retirees. Indeed, such people will be penalised because they will have to pay more tax to subsidise those people who receive the government's matching contribution in the years to come. Those existing retirees and those who are approaching retirement have lost forever the tax cut that they were promised they would receive on 1 January 1996.

The figures surrounding this budget are in many ways cooked figures. The government has recorded a so-called surplus of $718 million for the forthcoming financial year by cooking the books. It has cooked the books in various ways. The most important way in which it has done that is by including $5.3 billion—that is, $5,300 million—of once only asset sales. It has done this in a way in which the sales and sale conditions, which were explicitly ruled out by the government both before the last election and before the budget, have been transformed.

I refer in particular to the government's decision now to sell the remaining 50 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. According to the then finance minister, Mr Willis, a couple of years ago when the government sold off its second tranche of 19 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank, the government had given a cast-iron guarantee that it would under no circumstances whatsoever contemplate selling off any of the remaining 50 per cent. Yet in this budget it has announced that it will sell off the whole of the remaining 50 per cent. It is doing that simply because it is desperate to find some cash to fill that gaping hole in its accounts. It has also been forced—the coalition does not object to this; indeed, we told the government a year ago that it would probably need to do this—to increase the foreign ownership provisions of Qantas in advance of the forthcoming Qantas float to try again in a desperate bid to get more money into its coffers.

The real budget deficit is tucked away at the back of the budget papers. There are literally 1,000 pages of budget papers, and right down there in the last 50 pages or so you find the real budget outcome, as measured by the government's own official Bureau of Statistics. The real outcome is a budget deficit is $8.3 billion. It is not a surplus of $718 million, as the government portrayed on budget night. That $718 million surplus is a figure that has been struck after adjustments from accounting tricks and fiddles; the proceeds of asset sales; and, as I said, the cancelling of the significant $4 billion to $5 billion tax cut that the government promised that Australian taxpayers would receive from 1 January next year.

This is one of the highest taxing budgets that we have seen in our history. The real growth in revenue in 1995-96, as shown in the budget, is going to be 7.9 per cent. That follows growth in the year just being completed of 8.9 per cent. When you take account of inflation, the actual increases each year were several percentage points more than that. If we put together the figures for this year that has just been completed and the year we are just about to start, which the budget is all about, we have the highest growth in two consecutive years in government revenue—the government tax take—since the infamous Whitlam budgets of 1973 and 1974 which absolutely wrecked the Australian economy.

In this coming year alone, 1995-96, the government is going to rip off the Australian taxpayer an additional $14,200 million—a huge amount. Personal income tax is set to rise by 13 1/2 per cent. Indirect taxes are going to go up by about 15 per cent. This budget, which will have an effect over the next four years, increases taxes by $17,000 million. Compare that with the Prime Minister's promise at the last election of $14 billion of tax cuts over four years. What he is going to deliver over that same period is tax rises of $18 billion. In other words, the difference between what we have at the end of those four years and what he promised at the start, will be a $32 billion higher tax take by this government.

Mr Keating now has the uncontested title of the Prince of Broken Promises. I have already outlined some of these broken promises. He also promised before the last election not to put up tax as a proportion of national income. First of all, he said he was not going to put up tax at all and then he hedged his bets and said, `I really mean I won't put it up as a proportion of our total annual national income.' That is another broken promise. In the year in which he made that promise, tax revenue equalled 22.1 per cent of GDP; for the year ahead, the tax revenue is forecast to equal 24.2 per cent of GDP. So an extra 2.1 per cent of GDP is going to go in taxes and that, when translated into cold hard dollars, is more than $10,000 million of additional tax for that reason alone.

He also promised not to put up or to broaden indirect taxes. Since then, we have seen in the last couple of budgets and/or the budget we are now debating, sales tax rates up two per cent across the board. That was in the 1993 budget with effect over a couple of years, the next effect being from 1 July this year. We have seen the sales tax on cars go up in this budget from 15 or 16 per cent to 21 per cent, which is an increase of five per cent in the tax rate and an increase of 30 per cent in the amount taken in sales tax. We have seen certain building materials subject for the first time to a 12 per cent wholesale sales tax. Indeed, sales tax by the end of the coming financial year will have increased by 52 per cent since 1993 and, even after taking out inflation, it will have increased by 43.9 per cent—an absolutely staggering increase.

The government promised to cut company tax before the last election, and it did. That promise lasted for two years. This budget has now increased company sales tax by another three percentage points, from 33 per cent to 36 per cent, which is a proportionate increase of nine per cent. The election promise to cut personal income tax, which I have mentioned, is perhaps the daddy of them all, in terms of broken promises, but there are many others as well. There was an election promise not to put up the Medicare levy further. What happened? This budget has increased the Medicare levy. And so on it goes.

This budget hits the typical Australian family, the so-called battler, in a way that is almost unprecedented. The battler in Australia under this government has now become the battered. That applies across the board, but particularly to families and small businesses. The complacency of this government in its approach to the real financial and economic needs of this country is absolutely staggering and a matter of the gravest concern.

I repeat: this budget is a bad budget. It is inappropriate for the needs of Australia today. It is one of the highest taxing budgets in our history. It is built on broken promises. As such, it destroys and damages greatly the integrity of government—but, more particularly, it damages every Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills for 1995-96 represent the 13th budget of this Labor government. On 13 occasions this government has brought before this chamber these appropriation bills which are, in effect, statements of financial intent. They are statements of how the government intends to operate within the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Given the length of time that this government has been in charge of this country's economy, now is an appropriate—indeed, an essential—moment to stop and take a good hard look at the economic health of the nation. It is a chance to consider how well served by the government sector are the Australian people. As the owners and shareholders of the wealth of our nation, the Australian public deserves a clear and unambiguous report of the nation's condition. It is no more than any other shareholder in a company would demand, and it is no more than they deserve.

It is ironic therefore that the first point I regrettably feel I have to make is that, on any reasonable and fair assessment, the accounting reporting mechanisms underlying this budget are, at best, unhelpful and, at worse, misleading. It is not possible for all shareholders, all the Australian public, to understand the budget papers. As these reports are the most visible and public representation of the government's accounts, it is unreasonable to expect that members of the general public should essentially have to have an honours degree in accounting theory to be able to disentangle them and appreciate their meaning.

I make these comments without—and I stress this point—any criticism, implied or otherwise, of the Department of Finance or other officers who are responsible for preparing the budget papers. Those officers are professionals. They deserve credit for the task that they undertake. It must be extremely hard for these officers, when critical decisions affecting the budget's figuring and the explanatory text are not included until four days before the budget is to be delivered.

There are clearly two factors affecting the work of these people. The first is the very complexities of government accounting—and I know that the Department of Finance has commenced work on whole of government reporting in the context of the development of accrual accounting. I believe that this work will be earnestly and genuinely progressed, and I wish the officers well in this task.

The second factor impinging on the quality of the reports is the influence of the government over the structures of the reports. As the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has often boasted, the budget papers are the government's and, consequently, the format of reports and the text of reports are ultimately the responsibility of the government. I have no problem with this arrangement other than to note the capacity of a government to spin a picture to the public in the budget papers that is most favourable to its political fortunes.

What alternative is there to these current arrangements? I argue that the only real alternative to the present arrangements commences with the adoption, as a first principle, of the goal of transparency in respect of financial reporting. This would require that the operations and deliberations of central economic agencies be made more open and accountable to the public. Judgment of these agencies should be fully contestable in the public domain.

While, as I have already stated, I have no fundamental problem with the government of the day including its estimates of the core economic indicators in the budget papers, I do not believe that the public should be misled into believing these estimates are the considered judgments of the professionals in the Treasury. It is possible, I suppose, that the backroom staff of the Prime Minister's office may be better at predicting the future economic performance of Australia than the 500 staff of Treasury. It may even be possible that these same staff from the Prime Minister's office have superior economic skills to those of the entire private sector, such is the science of economic forecasting. Nevertheless, when the numbers in the budget papers are not those proposed by the Treasury, let the government clearly say so; let the government be honest with the Australian people.

In the same way, the budget papers should clearly enunciate any qualifications in the accounting basis of the budget reports. I acknowledge that these qualifications are included in the budget papers, but they are not up-front nor are they particularly clear.

For example, the first formal mention of budget surplus this year appears on page 1-1 of budget statement No. 1 in budget paper No. 1. However, it is not until page 7-2 in statement No. 2 of budget paper No. 1, some 399 pages later, that the budget papers define what the reported surplus means and notes that there are alternative measures which actually indicate that the budget is in deficit—such as the ABS budget deficit and the adjusted ABS budget deficit.

In estimate hearings recently, Deputy Secretary Thorn of the Department of Finance summed up the situation quite well when, in respect of what the various measures of the structural deficit meant, he stated, `Different things to different people.' Senator McMullan also indicated on that night, `I do not think that is a problem as long as people explain what they mean when they are using it.' I agree with Senator McMullan that it is important to be clear to all what a reported statistic means. I do, however, believe that there should be a clear and unequivocal agreement as to what reported figures in the Commonwealth budget mean.

To this end, I believe the budget should split the current and capital accounts in a manner that is generally accepted, both in the accounting profession and in a fashion that would produce reports that are generally understandable to the non-technically literate general public. I note that I have raised with the Department of Finance other matters in regard to the presentation of the budget papers. I am pleased to say that the department has agreed to investigate that and consider it for future years.

I would now like to explore what the figures reported in this budget mean for Australia. I begin with the broad statistics indicating the general state of the economy of Australia. Australia is deeply in debt. We owe the world a vast sum of money. At the end of March this year, the net foreign liabilities of Australian residents totalled $244,125 million. Of these liabilities, net foreign debt represented $166,919 million. That is the amount Australians owed to the rest of the world.

In fact, in the March quarter, Australia made payments totalling $5.8 billion in respect of income payable on foreign investment in Australia. For the first three-quarters of this financial year, the income payable by Australia on foreign investments has totalled $16.9 billion. This is a disturbing and negligent situation to be in. A debt of this proportion is no gift to our future generations. It is a shackle that, no matter what our constitutional arrangements, will constrain the hopes and aspirations of our children and sadly our children's children.

The rest of the world has reacted to Australia's debt and the policies that the government has put in place to respond to the level of our debt. The value of Australia's currency—our Australian dollar—when compared with the currencies of the rest of the world is a clear indication of how the rest of the world values our economy. At present, on a trade weighted index, our currency hovers with a nervous pulse just above its lowest level ever. In fact, our dollar has even depreciated 13 per cent against the New Zealand dollar since Christmas.

Domestically, the measures of Australia's economic performance are not too promising. At the broad level, our inflation rate is increasing. Australians will have to pay more for their goods and services over the next year. They will need to dig deeper into their savings to pay for the essentials of life. Unfortunately, those savings are declining at an alarming rate. Latest figures suggest that household savings are at their lowest level ever.

Over the next 12 months, it is forecast that more Australians will have gainful employment. However, recent statistics show that in large measure these new jobs will be part time. This means that, while our pool of unemployed continues to grow, our pool of underemployed also increases. Once again, this is a waste of our most valuable resource and a cause for great concern.

To make matters worse for the unemployed, it now seems that a myth is developing among certain sections of the media—no doubt led and encouraged by elements of the government's propaganda arm—to the effect that unemployment is not such a big problem and that everyone can have a job if they want it. This perverse manipulation of the Australian public's heart and soul is not merely deplorable but is absolutely dangerous. It opens the potential for the Australian community to walk away from their unemployed brothers and sisters with reckless abandon. Let it be clearly and unequivocally understood that the number one social and economic concern of this country must be ensuring employment for all those who want to work.

Now for the broad initiatives this government has delivered for Australia. Government revenue, that is, money obtained from the Australian people, is forecast to rise by 12.8 per cent in nominal terms, or 8.9 per cent in real growth. Either way it is a massive $14.2 billion. It includes a 13.6 per cent increase in individual income tax, a 13.3 per cent increase in company tax and other taxes and a 13.4 per cent increase in indirect tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Housing Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 is to amend the First Home Owners Act 1983 and other related legislation and the Housing Assistance Act of 1989. The decision to terminate the first home owners scheme was the result of a 1990 Hawke Labor government budget decision. As part of the winding down of the scheme, the bill removes the requirement in the First Home Owners Act of 1983 to report to parliament beyond the 1994-95 annual report. The bill also incorporates equivalent amendments to earlier first home ownership

SPEECH.PARA: assistance legislation, the Home Savings Grant Act 1964, the Home Savings Grant Act 1976 and the Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982.

PARA.TAB: The bill also amends the Housing Assistance Act 1989 to permit the Commonwealth minister to authorise and provide up to the full level of Commonwealth funding in the seventh and expected final grant year, 1995-96, of the current Commonwealth-state housing agreement in circumstances where a state has been or will be unable to meet its obligations under that agreement to match up to half of untied grants from the value of home loans made under home purchase assistance programs.

The first home owners scheme commenced on 1 October 1983 and provided assistance in the form of a subsidy towards mortgage repayments to those on low to moderate incomes to enable them to buy or build their first home. The coalition parties will not be opposing the bill as we have consistently believed the principle behind the devolution of the first home owners scheme to the states is correct and that these amendments are only to finalise a process begun by the First Home Owners Amendment Act 1990 which we did not oppose at that time.

I will now turn my comments to reflect on the position of home ownership. I think it is important to note that home ownership dominates Australia's housing picture. It is well documented that 96 per cent of Australians aspire to be home owners, and there is evidence that around 70 per cent of Australia's population either own a home or are in the process of purchasing one. Therefore, this preference for home ownership by an overwhelming majority of Australians does play an important role in making housing affordable during the course of their lives. All governments must take this preference seriously when framing overall housing policies.

Home ownership provides financial security for home owners and families and security of tenure. Home ownership also encourages savings and independence and instils a sense of pride and achievement. It is, of course, particularly relevant to people at the point where they retire or change their circumstances at a mature age.

The main issue affecting home buyers, particularly the first home buyer, remains affordability. Affordability depends largely on interest rates, real incomes and house prices. Changes in these factors, any one of them, affect the borrowing and purchasing power of potential home buyers. Increasing the level of home purchase amongst low income earners would reduce the demand for public housing and the associated costs on government revenue.

If we look for a moment at the Labor Party's economic environment and housing policy issues, there are a lot of issues that we need to address. We have now seen more than a decade of economic instability and volatility. We have seen a period of interest rate uncertainty and constant speculation. We have seen a sharp decline in housing finance commitments and building approvals. Building industry activity certainly is slowing, and this has become very obvious in recent time. As builders naturally rationalise their businesses, there are consequential job losses.

In this decade of Labor we have also seen very inconsistent strategies on high deficits. We have seen increased levels of uncertainty about future employment and expected income, particularly for lower income earners. We have seen increased inequality in the distribution of income amongst households throughout Australia and certainly a widening gap between mortgage loan repayments and wages in the community.

Of course, probably one of the major recent factors that are in the minds of many people is that Labor's budget of several weeks ago imposed a 12 per cent wholesale sales tax on certain building materials, higher sales taxes on vehicles, and higher company taxes—a double whammy, with accelerated payment schedules which may force smaller companies to lift prices further. We have also seen the announcement in the last week or so of significant changes in the area of termite control for housing activity. This will have consequential effects by again forcing up prices and housing. In the community there is a mistrust of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and his ministers on issues that relate to home purchase and the consequences that flow through to other families in the community who must rent their homes.

Amidst this environment of instability and volatility, Australians want to, and must, embark on the road of home purchase. First home buyers in the 1990s face many crucial decisions to enable them to achieve home purchase. They are more than likely to be two-income households. The female participation and spouse employment issues have now become profound in the community. Today Australian families will be prepared to delay having children. They will be prepared to buy in the outer suburbs, where housing is more than likely to be affordable. They will trade the distance to work and home size to achieve home ownership. And many Australians acknowledge there will be a limited cash flow for recreation and leisure as a result of their decisions to be involved in home purchase.

Some very interesting work was done recently by National Shelter on the cost of housing. In April of this year it had a report launched by the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, Mr Howe. A fundamental question was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: How do economic conditions impact on home ownership?
I quote from the report:
Generally, people are tenacious in hanging on to homes despite income-to-housing cost ratios. This means housing costs can swallow huge slabs of income to the detriment of other essential needs.
The answer goes on:

Home buyers in the lowest 40 per cent of income distribution are paying between 16 and 37 per cent of their gross incomes on housing, with many people paying over 30 per cent. Among low-income home purchases, financial problems are worst among poorer single women who pay on average 37.7 per cent of income on housing.

Mr Keating and Mr Howe showed little concern for the low to middle income home buyers when the government recently manipulated increases in interest rates. Certainly the consequences that flow from the wholesale sales tax on building materials not only will affect low and middle income groups but will very much affect groups in the community such as the ageing.

PARA.TAB: I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to consider the circumstances of many people who are choosing to retire and how often at that point in their life cycle people choose either to purchase a new home, and therefore suffer additional costs, or to embark on a period of renovation or adaption of their homes. Of course, there is no compensation in this year's budget for any of these people to assist them. This is a real slap in the face to many such people.

The real tragedy for the nation is that the actions of the Prime Minister are motivated by a desire to stay in power rather than weigh up and properly balance the issues that should be addressed in the national interest.

When it comes to looking at issues of housing, I am often asked: where is the Deputy Prime Minister, the housing minister, Mr Howe? When did the housing minister make a statement on the decline of housing affordability and/or home ownership? His department and a number of agencies have done a lot of work in addressing a lot of reports, but not one bit of it has ended up on the action table of the minister or in the budget statements of the government. There is a plethora of reports. Mr Howe has buried himself in this plethora of reports, strategies, visions, inquiries, agendas and reviews. The lucrative growth industry in construction and housing these days is not in building activity but in the work of consultants under the housing minister, Mr Howe. What are the results of these reports, strategies, visions, inquiries and reviews?

It is all right for Mr Howe, on almost a weekly basis, to come out with a new initiative, a new dream, but none of them are transposing into action programs that can be assessed as an improvement in the cost of housing or an improvement in the service delivery to people in tenancies or homes around Australia.

Mr Howe has constantly refused to acknowledge the impact his government's interest rate, high deficit and employment policies have on hundreds of thousands of Australian families. He has been ineffective and has shown absolutely no leadership in recognising the aspirations of Australians who wish to own their own homes or who are forced to accept the consequences of higher rent costs for those who cannot get into the home ownership cycle. Neither Mr Keating nor his housing minister offer any comfort to Australian home buyers and home owners—or, for that matter, home tenants.

The truth is that home ownership is under attack by Mr Howe, Mr Keating and the Labor government. The truth is that the Keating Labor government failed to keep its 1993 election promise to keep home purchase within the reach of those who want to buy their own home and to keep mortgage repayments at affordable levels.

By comparison, let me take the bait of some of my Labor Party colleagues opposite who often ask what a coalition government would do in this area. Let me give the assurance that we will establish a flexible, balanced response to the housing sector which can deliver home ownership as a real choice. We will provide alternative options for those who choose not to own or whose circumstances prevent them from owning their own home. We will operate economic policies that will ease the pressure on interest rates. That is the fundamental cost that underpins home ownership, home participation and home affordability in Australia today.

We will develop innovative reforms of financial arrangements in partnership with financial and industry groups in order to assist home buyers. A Liberal-National Party government will not neglect nor turn its back on the Australian community or the hundreds and thousands of Australian families currently sitting on the public housing lists or seeking to participate in an active form of home ownership. We would certainly deliver.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 is a relatively uncontroversial piece of legislation which, in the view of the Australian Democrats, the Senate should process with the minimum of fuss—considering the amount of work we have before us.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to make minor administrative amendments to two acts—or, to be more accurate, to one act and a bracket of acts. The first act to be amended is the Housing Assistance Act 1989. The second is the First Home Owners Act 1983 and other legislation related to its purpose, namely, the Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982, the Home Savings Grant Act 1964 and the Homes Savings Grant Act 1976.

The amendments to the Housing Assistance Act 1989 extend a waiver, which was legislated last year, to allow the Commonwealth to provide the maximum level of financial assistance for housing it has set aside for a particular state without that state having to match the contribution, as is required under the act. The background to this is that the Commonwealth provides untied financial assistance to the states under the Housing Assistance Act to deliver housing assistance, predominantly for building or purchase of public rental housing stock but also for home purchase, in accordance with the terms of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The current agreement is at schedule 1 of the existing act; the agreement is currently up for renegotiation.

The Commonwealth-state housing agreement requires states to match Commonwealth untied assistance on a dollar for dollar basis, with at least half of the matching provided through state grants and the balance through the value of loans made under various home purchase assistance schemes.

Difficulties with matching have apparently arisen in recent years for states as a result of a number of factors, including that great euphemism `changed market conditions', which is code for messing up their schemes. New South Wales is the best example. The affected states just have to say that they have been unable to provide additional grant funding to meet their matching obligations.

Prior to the amendments made to the act last year, the Commonwealth was required to recover financial assistance provided in earlier years from states which did not undertake sufficient lending under their home purchase assistance schemes. Similarly, where some states indicated that they were unlikely to be able to meet their matching requirements, the act, prior to amendment, required that the minister not provide unmatched funds, reducing untied grants to the level that would therefore be matched.

The government says it considered that either to recover financial assistance already provided or to reduce funding to be provided was undesirable. The Democrats would certainly agree. We believe that the level of funding, particularly for public housing, is already too low. To claw back or reduce funding would further disadvantage those very Australians most in need of assistance. In fact, due to funding cuts, public sector housing commencements have fallen by about 25 per cent over the past three years—and that number is still falling.

Public sector housing commencements were 11,998 in 1991-92; that dropped to 10,401 in 1992-93; that dropped again to only 8,272 in 1993-94; we are now looking at another drop to an estimated figure which is around the 6,800 mark in 1994-95. Over the same period public housing waiting lists have gone from 202,000 in 1990-91 to 216,000 in 1991-92 and to 232,000, nationally, as at 30 June 1993, the last available figure. We have to ask the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe): whose responsibility is this, minister? Yours? The states? Does it fall somewhere between the chairs? Surely it is about time somebody put up their hand and actually took responsibility.

One thing we do know for certain is that, on top of these figures, changes the government is seeking to make to rental assistance and other measures in this budget will certainly leave at least 410,000 people worse off. But more of that when the time comes, when we discuss the budget bills in this place.

The government did not expect at the time of the previous amendments that states would continue to have problems matching. Apparently they still do. So the amendments outlined in this bill extend these matching/waiving provisions for what is expected to be the final, and seventh year, of the current agreement. To coin a phrase, it is a matter of not matching/waiving, and the question must be asked of the states: why are they not matching?

The government says any decision to waive or reduce home purchase assistance requirements will be taken only after careful consideration of the circumstances leading to the need for such a course of action, and that that will occur on a case-by-case basis. The government also says the issue of matching will be addressed in the process of renegotiation of a new Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

I would ask the minister to reaffirm that the issue will indeed be addressed and to assure the Senate that states are not being allowed to shirk their commitment to public housing assistance simply as a matter of political expediency. In other words, their lack of matching funding has transparent, genuine reasons attached, not just poor excuses.

The second part of the bill before us concerns the First Home Owners Act 1983 and related legislation. The amendments are only to finalise a process begun by the First Home Owners Amendment Act 1990, which came out of the 1990 budget. Back then the government announced its decision to terminate the first home owners scheme as a part of its plan to restructure the Commonwealth home ownership assistance arrangements.

Legislation was introduced amending the First Home Owners Act 1983 so that it would not have effect in respect of homes acquired after that date. That legislation also fixed 30 June 1991 as the last date for applications for assistance under the act. However, applicants coming within those deadlines remained eligible for a stream of monthly assistance payments over five years from the date of acquiring their home.

Amendments in 1994 to the first home owners regulations allowed final payments to remaining eligible clients to be aggregated and brought forward. The bulk of these payments was made in November 1994. After 30 June 1995 there will be ongoing administrative activity only, of a minor administrative nature. In other words, the scheme has been wound up.

Accordingly, this bill amends the reporting requirements of the act to provide that no annual report on its administration and operation will be required after the 1994-95 report. This is entirely sensible.

Other amendments are included which are simply to tidy up outstanding loose ends. These include setting a deadline for appeals under the scheme and adjusting the secretary's power to prevent re-opening of appeals. For the very few decisions still to be made, normal rights of review and appeal via the AAT are retained, and clients will be notified of the new set of time lines before appeal rights expire.

When the government announced its decision to abolish the first home owners scheme the Democrats did not oppose it. We were, however, critical of the government's commitment to that scheme and to housing assistance in general. Nothing has changed to dispel that criticism. The cuts continue—cuts to public sector housing grants and now also to rent assistance. Those cuts are compounded by the continuing effects of financial deregulation, the result of which has been for the government to blithely allow the banks to keep their rates far higher than they should be; and at the same time to jack up fees on a whole range of different transactions and, for a whole range of reasons, on bank accounts of ordinary Australians. Your policies have literally given the banks a licence to print money—that is, profits—for themselves at the expense of Australian citizens generally.

While the Democrats support this bill, we put the government on notice that rhetoric can get you only so far. Eventually the people of this nation, as they did in the Canberra by-election, will tire of tricks and look at the real bottom line. Time is running out for you to get it right.

That these bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —These bills establish the basis for a national uniform heavy road vehicle registration charging scheme. The collection of charges under the scheme will contribute to recovery of the costs of wear caused by the operation of heavy vehicles. Amounts equivalent to the charges will be paid to the interstate road transport fund and distributed to the states and territories for the maintenance and upkeep of roads used by heavy vehicles. This is part of the reform processes developed by the National Road Transport Commission under the mandate of the Australian Transport Council, which is made up of Commonwealth, state and territory ministers.

PARA.TAB: This is an example of pegged legislation, where the Commonwealth passes legislation to apply in its jurisdiction and the states and territories pass similar legislation in their jurisdictions. It used to be called mirror legislation. The charges which are the subject of this bill are due to take effect on 1 July 1995. Similar legislation has already been passed in relation to driver licensing and the carriage of dangerous goods. The legislation will have no budgetary impact. However, it will result in charges increasing in some jurisdictions and falling in others. The charges will be calculated on an annual basis. They are set out in the schedule, which may be amended annually, but with no greater increase or decrease than five per cent per annum.

The bill also provides for the removal of the option to nominate an actual distance amount as the amount of registration charge payable and for the removal of the option to pay in instalments. References to motor vehicle and trailer charge monitoring devices are also removed.

The heavy vehicles agreement of the ministerial council foreshadowed the development of a more refined charging method following these initial changes. The new charging approach has the support of industry peak bodies, such as the Road Transport Forum, which wants a simple, uniform one-off charging system. The National Road Transport Commission has issued a discussion paper outlining options for more refined processes. This paper will be the basis of industry consultation.

All states except New South Wales and Western Australia have strongly supported the changes. The previous New South Wales government expressed concern about the financial impact of the changes because the new charges were substantially lower than the existing charges. The new New South Wales opposition believes the changes will be revenue neutral and should proceed. However, Bob Carr, following the very poor example of his close friend, Paul Keating, promised before the New South Wales election to implement these changes by 1 July 1995.

However, in true form, after the election he attached a rider saying that this would all depend on whether the other states and territories were in a position to proceed. Western Australia was originally opposed, due to the cost impact on intrastate operators. However, it has modified its opposition and is examining options for discounting the increase for intrastate operators. However, it may not be ready to proceed by 1 July. Victoria, Queensland and the ACT expect to introduce new charges by 1 July. South Australia and Tasmania are committed, but will not pass legislation until July or August. The Northern Territory will enact but not implement until other states and territories have legislation in place.

Generally, this is a non-controversial bill which is supported by the opposition as an important part of the micro-economic reform process of the road transport industry. It is important that interstate truckers do not have to go through a raft of bureaucratic mazes to comply with differing state and territory laws. However, it should be pointed out that Bob Carr's about-face will cause significant problems. At the annual conference of the New South Wales Livestock Transport Association a few weeks before the New South Wales election, the ALP transport spokesman, Brian Langton, was asked whether a Carr government would implement these uniform registration charges by 1 July 1995, and his answer was that it would. Bob Carr indeed put this promise in writing to the Australian road transport forum coordinator. Now the New South Wales government is saying it will only implement it when the other states and territories do likewise. All I can say is that that is par for the course.

It should also be pointed out that the National Road Transport Commission has calculated that a user pays charge for heavy road transport vehicles equates to 18c a litre in fuel excise. At present road transport operators pay 32.5c a litre in fuel excise. There has been no attempt by the government to rebate the excess. The average semitrailer operators pay $66,400 a year in taxes and charges to the Commonwealth and the states. The 5c a litre increase in fuel excise in the 1993 budget increased this impost by $6,000 a year.

The government is significantly decreasing the amount of money that it is spending on roads. In the 1992 budget prior to the last election, the government said it would spend some $1,600 million on roads. In this year's budget it says it will spend only $840 million. Compare this with 1982, under a coalition government, when $150 million was spent on roads, and fuel excise was 6c a litre. With those reservations, we support the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not oppose the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill, which are part of an ongoing program for standardisation between the states of charges, processes and so on. I wish to comment only briefly that both this government and the state governments have given so much attention to road transport and so little attention to rail. I draw attention to the way in which, within a week of the budget being brought down, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced in South Australia $130 million for 8 1/2 kilometres of freeway down through the Adelaide Hills—which amount was not mentioned anywhere in the budget—despite the fact that the railway which runs down through the Adelaide Hills was last realigned back in 1927 and is in desperate need of realignment to improve rail transport through the hills.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, in the south-east of South Australia, the 220 kilometres of line to Mount Gambier would cost only $8 million to standardise but, because it is broad gauge, it has been cut off entirely by the standardisation of the Adelaide to Melbourne line, leaving the people and all the industries of the south-east without rail transport. Despite very considerable efforts on my part in the lead-up to the budget to get $5 million from this federal government to standardise and upgrade that line, the money has not been forthcoming. Yet the Prime Minister could pork-barrel in South Australia to the tune of $130 million within a week of the budget—an amount which did not appear anywhere in the budget.

I just wanted to make those few remarks on the road transport legislation to draw attention to the fact that, whilst we do not object to this legislation—it is desirable that there be legislation for uniform road charges and all the other things in the legislation—there is an urgent need for this government and the state governments to do a great deal more than they have done in the area of rail transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad, Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, that you are in the chair at this time; I will come back to that later. It was interesting to hear Senator Coulter's contribution about the amount that was announced for that freeway in South Australia but which did not appear in the budget. Perhaps I should put on record here that it will probably come out of the road funding budget for Western Australia, like the $8 million last year that was put into the Subiaco oval. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Human Services and Health and member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) opened it and were grandstanding and congratulating the government about how good that $8 million for the Subiaco oval was. It is not that I have anything against developing the Subiaco oval—
—Just pledge now that you will never use it.
—I use it every second Saturday. They got the praise for the $8 million but, unfortunately, the lack of road funding with the $8 million was not mentioned.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill which will standardise interstate road transport for heavy vehicles, that is, anything over eight and a half tonnes, as I have had a bit to do with heavy road transport. These bills come forward at a rather unique time as only last week the first standard-gauge train went from Brisbane to Perth. Western Australia held out on this for a long time, and justifiably so because we were not going to be well treated by it in the first place, but I now welcome it.

The amendment bill takes away the option of using the actual distance and goes to a flat licence for interstate trucks. I believe that is the way to go. For a start, measuring devices break down; secondly, they can be tampered with. There are a couple of measures I question, though. I understand there are to be no instalments for the 12-month payment of around $4,200, I believe it is, for one prime mover and one trailer. I understand there is to be one payment only. PARA.EMPHASIS: DIVIDING BILLS TO DEAL WITH HOBSON'S CHOICE

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of dividing a . . . bill is to facilitate the Senate's consideration of a matter—to give the Senate an opportunity of voting separately and effectively on all the issues involved and, should it be necessary, to thwart any possible tacking provisions in a bill the effect of which may be to infringe the Senate's constitutional power of amendment. (Odgers, Australian Senate Practice, 6th ed., p 464)

Since long before the 1600s when the phrase first entered the language, it has been an elementary political tactic to leave an opponent with Hobson's choice: this one or nothing; my choice or none. At his Cambridge inn, Thomas Hobson enjoyed a kind of monopoly which allowed him to offer each customer only the horse nearest the stable door—"that or none". Government, too, enjoys monopolistic tendencies. In the legislature it has powers of initiative, resources of drafting and control of timing. Sometimes it offers the Senate only Hobson's choice—our bill or our interlocked package of bills or no other. The command, to pass all, or bear the opprobrium of denying all, can be intimidating. In such circumstances, mere amendments may not be a politically adequate response.

Take the example of the Senate, after considering a bill received from the House of Representatives, passing a motion requesting the House to make an amendment whose effect is to increase an appropriation in the bill. The bill, containing many provisions with which the Senate may agree, is not given a third reading until the fate of the request has been determined by the House. Depending on the bill, accusations of Senate delay or obstruction are politically easier to make than if the bill had been, say, divided into two self-contained bills and it made clear that one of them was agreed to by the Senate: it awaited only the House of Representatives to agree to the Senate's amendments creating that bill and it would be law, whatever the fate of its twin.

Or take the case of a House of Representatives social security bill designed to deliver a mix of increased and decreased benefits. For both practical and political reasons, such bills are sometimes scheduled to arrive in the Senate late in a sittings with an administratively "irrevocable" commencement date usually coinciding with the end of the sittings. If the Senate makes, and then insists on or presses, amendments or requests disagreed to by the House of Representatives it may be claimed that passage of the whole measure is jeopardised, the Senate is denying recipients their new or increased benefits, and injustice and chaos will result. In the predictable game of bluff, government in its rhetoric will hold the Senate responsible for an outcome vastly more detrimental to all beneficiaries than the proposed Senate amendments might have been beneficial to some. Again, a possible solution is to divide the bill into two or more self-contained bills, making it clear in the message to the House of Representatives that the Senate has given a third reading to one of the bills and postponed the third reading of the other, perhaps referring its provisions to a committee.

Again, a House of Representatives bill may contain an assortment of mismatching amendments to one Act, or too diverse a collection of amendments to several Acts. To some of these, agreement or rejection may be easy, while to others overhasty acceptance or rejection may be irresponsible. Like the bill itself, Senate opposition to clauses, or amendments to strike out provisions, can amount to a reversed Hobson's choice. Often, the Senate would be agreeable to passing, say, half of the bill, and seeking time to consider the other half but without delaying enactment of the first half. Again this could be graphically signalled to the House of Representatives by dividing the bill in two, agreeing to one bill, deferring consideration of the other, returning the divided bill by message to the House, thereby placing the onus on it to agree the new bill.

Perhaps the most dramatic recent example of this political Hobson's choice involved the 1993 budget legislation. An omnibus Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, proposed nine sets of major amendments to seven tax-related acts encapsulating the fiscal heart of the budget statement. Tax cuts were mixed with various tax rises. More than one latter-day Thomas Hobson in government demanded "that or none". The constitutional validity of the bill was challenged by independent legal opinions which concluded that the bill simultaneously imposed tax, dealt with more than one subject of tax and dealt with matters other than the imposition of tax, in contravention of section 55 of the Constitution. Eventually the bill was withdrawn and redrafted by the government, ultimately in the form of eleven bills. In any event, attempts were made in the Senate, as a matter of principle, to divide some of these bills in order to place distinct subjects of taxation in separate bills (see appendix 2).

Similar problems may arise in the future. The Minister of Finance, Mr Beazley, MP, (ALP) has been reported as suggesting that "the political tactic of presenting the [1995] Budget as an interlocked package [will] help the Government put pressure on the Senate to agree to its fiscal plans". It was proposed, he said, to use a deficit reduction structure `very cleverly and very highly focused" to produce such pressure (Financial Review, 6 February 1995, p 5). Indeed, when in 1993, the omnibus taxation bill was recast by the government into eleven separate bills, one was described, drafted, and enacted as a test bill (the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.2) 1993). It contains a mixture of provisions similar to those considered by the Senate, its legal committee and independent lawyers as possibly breaching section 55 of the Constitution. That the 1993 test bill was never tested may embolden the government in 1995.

Dividing a bill is one Senate procedure specifically designed to deal with this and other examples of Hobson's choice in legislation—a way to reshuffle the horses at the stable door by dividing the bill into its constituent parts in the form of, say two self-contained bills and then making it clear that no. 1 is agreed to but no. 2, being unpalatable, is not. Agreement to the provisions of the no. 2 bill can be postponed while it is examined by a committee prior to being agreed to, amended or rejected. Such a process can be used without jeopardising the major structure of the original bill which, in the form of the no. 1 bill, will have been agreed to by the Senate and returned to the House of Representatives for its agreement. Such a new bill, having as part of the original bill received its first, second and third reading in the House, does not need to repeat that process—the division of the original into several bills is merely an amendment to which the House can simply agree, thereby enacting the no. 1 bill.

Before explaining further, a word of caution—this is not a procedure for the merely results-driven politician, the architect of great reforms, impatient with democracy and its inevitable tedium of mere process. It is a procedure, therefore it is all process—the reductive process of identifying the bare essentials of political disagreement rather than exaggerating them. Governments use rhetoric and exaggerate. Senates are at least more inclined to use process and reduce. Public opinion should be aware of the difference and its consequences.

In using the procedure, a first option maybe to move, by notice, leave or suspension of standing orders, or as an amendment to the bill's second reading "that the minister withdraw the bill and redraft it" in a specified form (for example, "as two separate bills, one dealing with X, the other dealing with Y "); or move "that the bill be returned to the House of Representatives with a message requesting that the bill be redrafted by being divided into a bill for X and a bill for Y ". This was the course adopted in 1975 on the Corporations and Securities Industry Bill whose length and complexity made it very difficult for the Senate drafter to divide into several coherent bills. A limitation of this approach, however, is that the bill does not reach the stage at which the Senate can demonstrate its agreement to those agreeable portions of it. Thus, it does not reach the third reading stage in the Senate before being returned to the House of Representatives and the Senate's action is, therefore, easily confused with rejection or obstruction.

Another option is to divide the bill in the Senate. An instruction may be given to a committee of the whole to divide a bill into two or more bills (SO 150(1)). (Several bills can also be consolidated into one.) Normally a notice of motion of the proposed instruction must be given and that motion may be moved immediately after the second reading of the bill (SO 115(2)(b)). A motion for an instruction may also be moved by leave.

In practice a contingent notice of motion is given—"that (contingent on the AB Bill being read a second time in the same or substantially the same form as it was read a first time) I shall move that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole on the bill that the committee (a) divide the bill so as to incorporate into two (three, four) bills the provisions relating to A and the provisions relating to B (and the provisions relating to C etc); and (b) report each of the bills separately."

When the contingent event occurs (ie as soon as the second reading is agreed to) the motion for the instruction may be moved ("that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole . . . that the committee divide the bill etc"). This motion may be debated with up to 30 minutes for each speaker and no overall time limit; being a procedural rather than a substantive motion, the mover has no right of reply (Ruling of President Gould, 1 October 1909).

Some House of Commons precedents (although not binding on the Senate) hold that an instruction is in order only if the relevant bill "is drafted in two or more distinct parts, or otherwise lends itself to such division into parts", (May, 21st ed., p 483). Odgers notes that "[l]ong and complex bills do not lend themselves easily to division" (6th ed., p 461). (This may justify returning the bill to the House of Representatives seeking (in effect from the government) its redrafting as two or more bills: see the Report of the Ninth Conference of Presiding Officers and Clerks, Parliamentary Paper No. 223/1978, p 215).

Usually a bill which amends other Acts can, with a little time and careful redrafting, be reduced to two or more bills incorporating each of the constituent parts of the original bill. A bill which does not amend other Acts may occasionally be more difficult to divide as numerous common provisions may need to be duplicated in the amendment creating the two bills.

In either case, further amendments must be relevant to the bill in question. The Senate adopts generous rules of relevance to facilitate debate and amendment. But if relevance is in serious doubt, a motion may be moved for an instruction to the committee of the whole to consider an amendment not relevant to the bill but relevant to an Act to be amended by the bill. Where such a problem is anticipated the original notice and motion for an instruction may contain the requirement both to divide the bill and consider certain amendments. If the bill in question is not one amending other Acts, an irrelevant amendment may be moved only after the committee has been empowered to consider it by a motion suspending standing orders.

In any event, if the motion for an instruction is agreed to, the committee of the whole is under an order to carry it out, ie to divide the bill. The actual division requires a further motion, in committee of the whole, to bring about the drafting needed to physically create two (or more) bills from one, by a series of amendments. If agreed, a subcommittee of the committee of the whole could be appointed to draw up the amendments forming the two bills, if this was politically acceptable to the chamber (Odgers 6th ed., p 466). Usually though, the Senator moving for the instruction has had the amendments drawn up. Once divided, the committee can agree to further, substantive amendments (or requests) to either or both bills, or report progress on one bill and resume consideration of the other.

The Senate has never actually agreed to an instruction to divide a bill though numerous motions have been made to achieve the same end. For example, on 4 December 1991 (but using suspension of standing orders rather than an instruction) Senator Parer (Lib) moved to divide the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 into two bills, one relating to political broadcasts, the other relating to political disclosures. His purpose was to separate provisions banning certain political advertising (which he opposed) from provisions requiring disclosure of political funding (which he supported). The attempted division was, therefore, a direct challenge to the Hobson's choice built into the bill—"the combination of both proposals or none". Senator Parer's motion provided that the first bill consist of the enacting words and certain Parts and clauses of the original bill; that the second bill consist of a certain Part of the original bill; that the first bill be amended to have an appropriate title and renumbered clauses; that the second bill be amended to insert clauses etc; that the two bills be printed and be considered separately on the next day. (The full text of the motion is set out for reference in appendix 1.)

Another example involved the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993, one of the eleven bills into which the single Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 referred to above was eventually divided by the government after its constitutionality was challenged. On 20 October 1993, Senator Hill (Lib) moved "that the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments to the bill ", namely that it be divided into four bills, one relating to fringe benefits tax, two relating to income tax rates and one relating to medicare levy. His purpose was to enable clear discrete voting choices on separate, constitutionally valid, bills rather than Hobson's choice on a single, composite, possibly unconstitutional bill. (Even as one of eleven extrapolated bills, the (No. 1) Bill was still a composite of at least four measures.)

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dividing a tax bill by a request

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill's motion requested the House of Representatives to divide the bill so that the first bill consist of the enacting words and certain Parts of the original bill; and the second bill consist of a certain Division of the original bill; the third bill consist of a certain Division and Part of the original bill; the fourth bill consist of a certain Part of the original bill; and that each new bill have words of enactment, commencement clauses etc. This proposal was debated in committee of the whole with all the advantages of such a forum—up to fifteen minutes per speaker on as many occasions as necessary while debate continued. (The full text of the motion is set out for reference in appendix 2.)

These are the only requests for amendments dividing a bill ever considered by the Senate in committee of the whole. Senator Hill moved this motion in the form of a request to the House of Representatives to divide the bill because, by virtue of section 53 of the Constitution, the Senate has no constitutional power to amend a bill imposing tax or a bill appropriating money for the ordinary annual services of the government. It can merely request the House of Representatives to amend such bills. It was considered that as the composite tax bill imposed a tax, it was unamendable because of section 53, and could be the subject only of requests for amendments even though the amendments sought only to divide the bill into constituent parts.
In summary then, where time permits, the normal procedure to divide a bill is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: .give a contingent notice of motion that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the bill;

SPEECH.PARA: .this is followed, after the second reading of the bill, by a motion moving such an instruction;
.in the committee of the whole a series of amendments is moved to amend the bill, literally to create two or more bills from it;
.other substantive amendments (or requests) can be moved and progress on one bill reported while the other continues in committee;
.the committee reports that the bill is amended by being divided into a first bill and a second bill etc;
.the motion to adopt the report of the committee of the whole may provide that the third reading of the second or objectionable bill be postponed;
.the first bill may then be given a third reading by the Senate;
.the message to the House of Representatives recounts this sequence of events, setting out the amendments made to create the two bills;
.the House may agree to these amendments, in effect enacting the new bill to which the Senate has already agreed;
.the provisions of the second bill remain under consideration in the Senate.

More often than not, time, tactics, or circumstances render this instruction procedure inappropriate and more expeditious avenues are needed to divide a bill. From the Senate's point of view, the political goals are the same: to divide Hobson's bill into two or more bills to expedite passage; to make voting options clear and unencumbered; and to lay the furphy of Senate obstruction by placing uncontentious measures in one bill, giving it a third reading and returning it to the House of Representatives for agreement, while placing more controversial measures in another bill for further consideration. On such further consideration, that "new" bill could be agreed to or amended and returned to the House, or rejected, laid aside, and/or replaced by an entirely new bill (as long as such a new bill can be introduced in the Senate).

Expedited procedures invariably involve suspensions of standing orders either to move an instruction without notice or to go further and actually divide the bill in the Senate and have the new bills printed before their separate consideration in committee of the whole (as Senator Parer sought to do).

The following examples illustrate the use of expedited procedures. On 8 September 1981, Senator Harradine gave a contingent notice for an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981 to incorporate certain measures in a separate bill. He later withdrew this notice and the Senate requested the House to make numerous amendments to the bill. However, on 23 September 1981 the Senator gave another notice that, contingent upon the receipt of a message from the House indicating that it had not made those amendments, he would move that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the bill to incorporate separate measures in a separate bill as proposed in his previous contingent notice. (The requests were not made and Senator Harradine choose not to use his contingent notice: see Odgers, 6th ed., p 467.)

On 27 October 1982, after the second reading of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982, Senator Grimes (ALP) moved that so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent him moving that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the bill to incorporate certain clauses and Parts in a separate bill.

Again, as noted above, on 2 December 1991, Senator Parer gave a notice of motion that, contingent on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 being read a second time, he would move to suspend standing orders to propose the division of the bill. He moved the motion on 4 December 1991 (see appendix 1) dividing the bill. In addition, however, his motion provided that the "new" bills be considered separately, be taken as each having been read a second time (the second reading of the original bill had been agreed to) and be printed as separate bills for consideration in committee of the whole on the next day. When this motion was negatived, Senator Parer used the more usual contingent notice, given on 2 December 1991, to move that it be an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the bill. The rationale was that the Senate having rejected his proposed division of the bill would have a second chance to propose its own division.

Similarly on 9 December 1994, Senator Harradine (Ind) moved to suspend standing orders to enable him to move a motion for an instruction to the committee of the whole to divide the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 to incorporate in a separate bill a schedule dealing with parliamentarians' remuneration. He thought this schedule should not have been intermixed with this bill. The original bill, without the schedule, dealt with uncontentious coal industry reforms which he wished to support while postponing the third reading of his proposed "new" bill dealing with remuneration.

At the 1978 Presiding Officers' Conference, Odgers stressed that "dividing a bill is nothing more than amending it" but he characterised the procedure as an "essential" power of "profound" importance to a house of review, the antidote to unfair practices like tacking, combining unrelated matters, mixing popular and unpopular measures—in effect the answer to Hobson's choice (p 213, 214 and 216). The Tasmanian and South Australian Parliaments have divided bills and agreed to the resulting new bills. The President of the South Australian Legislative Council, AM Whyte, told the 1978 Conference that "the right of the House to split bills where it sees unrelated matters, some of which can be passed without great consideration, and a matter which needs detailed debate and detailed research, is most necessary" (p.233) .

The Senate (in spite of the efforts of some tactically minded senators), while recognising the procedural possibilities of dividing bills, has not yet agreed to divide a bill. But when the circumstances arise the procedure is available as a powerful answer to Mr Hobson's "my bill or none"!
Peter O'KeeffeMarch 1995
Clerk Assistant (Procedure)
