TALK.START.PARA: —The government will impose a total of an additional $13.9 billion in taxes on Australians next financial year. Unlucky 13 seems to have been the government's number in this year's budget. There will be no second round One Nation tax cuts. The l-a-w tax cuts are no more—it seems there is one law for average Australians and another law for the Keating government.

PARA.TAB: The Medicare levy, which is a tax, will increase again despite the government's assurances that this would never need to happen. The tax office is to crackdown on certain labour relationships, which it does not like because they have revenue implications, even though those arrangements have been entered into by Australians as a result of this government's previous taxation policies. Company tax will increase by three per cent to 36 per cent. This is a 10 per cent increase in tax for Australian businesses, a vast number of which are still struggling to recover from the recession we had to have and the recession that this government actually manipulated.

New sales taxes will be introduced for a large range of building materials. This will have serious implications for an important sector of the economy. A 30 per cent increase in sales tax will be applied to non-luxury motor vehicles. This is a cynical act that exposes the illegitimacy of the government's actions taken in 1992 to bring the rate down to 16 per cent. In fact, there are 13 pages of revenue measure changes in the budget which will add to the previously announced measures that increase all sales tax rates by one per cent and bring forward corporate tax payments.

On the expenditure side the government has triumphed its tight fiscal outcome. That outcome will see government outlays rise next year by $1.3 billion, if you include asset sales, which is not fair, or by $6.3 billion if you excluded them. This is the most difficult point for the ordinary person to appreciate.

Receipts from sales of physical assets are recorded as offsets within outlays to assist the measurement of the net stock of capital assets in the economy. Thus the proceeds from the sale of the assets serve to reduce outlays, which is a measure of the government's economic activity. So this year, after raising taxes by an historical level and increasing outlays, the government has still been forced to turn to asset sales to balance the books. After taking more and more money from the pockets of Australians, this government has found it necessary to sell the nation's assets just to make the books balance. What a sale!

In the next financial year, the government will sell in excess of $5 billion of the country's assets. Will these sales be used to invest in the infrastructures of Australia? Will the revenue from these sales be used to reduce the nation's bankcard debt? No. This government is an expenditure addict. It just cannot help spending. As soon as money falls into its hands, it has to spend it. Money burns holes in this government's pockets.

Sadly, the result of this profligate spending can be seen in the monthly bankcard bill, our balance of payments and the current account deficit. We have to pay back not a couple of million dollars per month or a couple of hundred million dollars per month but over $2 billion per month. Unbelievably, this government argues that this is a good result. A good result! One can only imagine what a bad result might mean. It reminds me of the Black Knight in Monty Python's In search of the Holy Grail. With both arms and both legs cut off, the knight calls out to his slayer, `It's just a flesh wound.'

Sadly, this is no joke. Our country is haemorrhaging and the government thinks it is a good result. Heaven help the nation if the USA heads into recession and our exports of elaborately transformed manufactures should decline. This government has wilfully ignored our trading plight. No truckload of statistics will change the undeniable fact that our country must act to support business, not destroy it. But what could we expect from a Prime Minister who could not even hold down a basic salesman's job and a government whose ministers have no basic experience in operating even the most simple businesses.

To ever improve this trading disaster, the nation must make some hard decisions about where we are going and how we are going to get there. These decisions must be made soon, as the rest of the world, particularly our major trading partners, made these decisions long ago. As long as we hide our heads in the sand, lock ourselves in the bedroom and act with pique and disdain for the world around us, the living standards of all Australians will continue to fall.

Our labour regulation laws must be reviewed and employees freed from the senseless regulation of their lives by the dead hand of bureaucracy, subject to the provision of a reasonable and genuine safety net. We must reduce our fiscal cancer of high government expenditure. Whether government expenditure is high relative to other nations or not, it continues to limit the potential of this country to grow at a sustainable rate to allow for employment growth and low inflation. At present, as soon as our growth rate exceeds three per cent, the fear of inflation pushes up our interest rates and chokes our industry. At the same time, without growth of around four per cent, our unemployment queues lengthen and social misery increases. How, in a country so rich in resources and so rich in innovation and enterprise, can this situation be allowed to occur?

It is time that the government of Australia took positive steps to give back the nation to its people. It is only the people of Australia who can care for the environment, produce wealth and jobs and look after those who are disadvantaged or incapacitated in any way; it is only the people of Australia who can establish a future for generations to come.

What does this budget bring for the Australian people? It brings higher taxes, lower economic growth, more debt, the sale of the country's assets and more pain for the productive and employing small businesses of this country. This is a budget that only a 13-year-old tired government could have produced. This budget, like the ministers and government backbenchers who will hawk it to the Australian public, is full of rhetoric and hollow, empty promises. Let no-one be in doubt that this budget is a cynical and complacent exercise. While the coalition will not oppose these appropriation bills, let no-one be in any doubt that the coalition believes this is a budget that has failed Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on the appropriation bills, with particular reference to Antarctica. I will refer to comments I made the other night at an estimates committee hearing. My colleague Senator Gibson has just talked about taxation and the inappropriate way in which the government has tackled the budget. I must say that the Antarctic division has been pruned rather severely in the last two years. I have been concerned about the effect that will have on research projects and the day-to-day running of the division. It has also forced the division into a situation where it has reduced its two ship option to one ship.

PARA.TAB: I have been concerned for quite some time about the effect that might have on the safety of our expeditioners and researchers in Antarctica. I found out at the estimates committee hearing that the budget this year will be cut by almost $1 million. Although it will not have an immediate effect, the director informed me that it will have an effect further down the track. As I said, I have had a more than passing interest in the one ship option and the contracts regarding shipping and the building of the Aurora Australis a few years ago.

During the estimates committee hearings, I again raised the question of the charter costs of the Icebird and the Aurora Australis. This year in the budget I noticed the division was expecting another $2.5 million allocation for shipping. After having been told last year that it was going to be a one ship operation and that it would employ another ship every three years, lo and behold, less than 12 months later, the division is looking at chartering the Icebird—the name has been changed to the Polarbird. Less than 12 months later the division has changed its mind again. I do not blame the director for this. It is because of the severe cutbacks caused by the government. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has gone again now. As I said, I am concerned about the result of this bill in relation to safety in Antarctica.

One of the major things I wanted to do was find out the cost of chartering the Icebird last year and how much it has cost in the past. Every time we talk about charter rates the minister throws up his hands and says, `I'm sorry.' In the estimates committee hearing, the director said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot—
divulge the charter cost—
My recollection is that there is a confidentiality stamp across the whole contract.

I raised with them the fact that on a previous occasion when trying to find out the confidentiality of Mr Hill's contract with the ABC the estimates committee was of the opinion that the documents had to be forwarded. In this particular case, the minister said:
It took a particular decision that is not the case in relation to the confidentiality clauses in these contracts.

He was referring to the contract of the Icebird. I wanted to find out the difference between the charter rate offered last year and what it was going to cost the taxpayers this year. Unfortunately, that information was refused once again. The minister said:
I think there is a very significant risk that the Commonwealth would be in breach of contract if in fact the information that has been sought was disclosed.

I noticed during the week in an AAP release in Melbourne that a report was tabled in the parliament by the Victorian Auditor-General. He, too, sounded his concerns about the confidentiality of some of the executive officer contracts. He said that he was initially refused access to the required documents on the grounds that the contracts were confidential between the employee and employer. They are not quite the same as a contract between a government department and a shipping company, but the principles of commercial-in-confidence and making these things available still apply. So the Auditor-General in Victoria has raised the same doubts.

PARA.TAB: In the report of the environment, sport and territories estimates committee, my colleagues and I made some general comments. I will quote from a couple of areas in the report to senators. In 2.1 of the report, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a request by Senator Calvert for information contained in the contract for the charter of the supply ship, Icebird was refused on the grounds of commercial confidentiality.

The committee also pointed out that similar situations had arisen at additional estimates on 29 November 1994 when the ABC refused to provide details on the contract of the outgoing director, David Hill. The important part is, as the report said:

The Committee is concerned that confusion still appears to exist as to the duty of government agencies and bodies to provide information to Parliamentary committees. As this Committee stated in its report of December 1994, the over-riding principle was stated clearly in the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, ABC Employment Contracts and their Confidentiality (December 1986).
Importantly, it says:

. . . "authorities must be prepared to account to Estimates Committees for all aspects of their financial management and administration, even when the information sought may be regarded as private or commercially confidential."
Further in the general comments of the committee, it says:
In other words, it is something for the committee to determine, not the witness.

In other words, it was not for the minister, nor was it for Mr Moncur, the director of the Antarctic division, to say that they could refuse information that I had requested; it was up to the committee to decide whether I should receive that information. The estimates committee report to the Senate also said:
A government department or statutory authority has no power to unilaterally withhold information simply because in its own opinion the information should be confidential.
It went on to say:

This Committee noted in its December 1994 report that, under the revised Standing Orders which came into effect on 10 October 1994, Legislation Committees when considering Estimates, (unlike the former estimates committees)—
and this is where I think the minister may have got his wires crossed—
had a formal power to call for persons and documents, although (like the former Estimates Committee) they have no power to take evidence in private.
At the request of Senator Kernot of the Australian Democrats, the first Senate privileges report highlighted the fact that:
. . . on several recent occasions the government has failed to comply with orders and requests of the Senate.
The Committee of Privileges came to the conclusion that it is for the relevant house to take action under its contempt powers as it considers appropriate in the circumstances. In other words it:

does not accept the concept that jurisdiction in respect of the determination of claims of executive privilege or public interest immunity against a house of Parliament or its committees should be conferred on the courts;

That is rather technical. The second report in March 1995 is more explicit. It dealt with the Casselden Place matter. Page 3—and these are the very important words when the issue of commercial-in-confidence is raised—states:

In particular, authorities must be prepared to account to Estimates Committees for all aspects of their financial management and administration, even when the information sought may be regarded as private or commercially confidential. This aspect of statutory authority accountability should be made clear at the time an authority enters into negotiations for any type of contract and should be made clear in the terms of contracts entered into.
The report concludes:
The Committee reaffirms the comments made in its 49th Report—
which I referred to just a moment ago—
that any claims of executive privilege or public interest immunity are ultimately for a House of Parliament to determine . . .

Then the report goes on to make some other comments. In other words, twice now the Senate Committee of Privileges has put down its view on commercial-in-confidence. From memory, during the last three or four estimates committee hearings I have been refused under the guise of commercial-in-confidence information that I think is important for the parliament to know.

PARA.TAB: I believe taxpayers' interests have to be served. I do not believe contracts have been let and moneys wasted intentionally, but I think I should have had the opportunity to highlight that generous offers were made last year by, in this particular case, the company that owned the Icebird. By not accepting the offer that was made last year and then having, as a result of government bungling on the budget, to turn around and charter this vessel this year, we might have missed out on quite considerable savings for the taxpayers of Australia. Because this commercial-in-confidence clause has been used, I have been unable to find out about these matters and report them to the public.

The reason I stand here today commenting on this is to bring to the Senate's attention again—I am sure this will be discussed when the report on the estimates comes forward—that ministers of the government have been using this commercial-in-confidence power to hide the real story. I believe senators have the right to find out at estimates committees what is happening with taxpayers' dollars. After all is said and done, that is what estimates committees are about: inquiring into where money is being spent, where it is going, what is being wasted and what is being saved. In this case, if these figures had been made available I think I would have been able to show that, because of government budget restrictions and alterations in shipping procedures over the last couple of years, not only have a lot of the government research programs in the Antarctica been put at risk but also lives of our expeditioners may have been put at risk at one stage or another.

I will leave it at that, because I know other speakers are waiting, except to say that when we are talking about the appropriations I think it is also very important to talk about what happens in estimates committees and the way some ministers use different devices to keep cost overruns and the like from members of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the appropriation bills. It is most appropriate that we now focus on the budget after enduring all this week the obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with turning this country into a republic. We can now get back to what really is important to ordinary Australians—that is, the state of the economy, taxation and unemployment. As most of you know, only one per cent of Australians think the republic is important; the majority think that what really matters, and what is really concerning this country, is the economy.

PARA.TAB: The budget that this government has presented, and that we are debating, is a classic financial statement from the Labor Party. It is a tax and spend budget. We have in this budget the most extraordinary increases in taxation which have not yet sunk into the psyche of the Australian people as they try to get rid of the cloud put upon them by Mr Keating and his republic. But the tax effect of this budget will sink into the Australian psyche and will destroy this government at the election.

There has been a 13.9 per cent increase in personal income tax in this budget; a 15.4 per cent increase in company tax, which ends up being paid by consumers and taxpayers; and a 13.4 per cent increase in sales tax, which is paid at the end of the day by ordinary Australians. Total revenue to the government is increasing 12.8 per cent. That total is up nearly $14 billion, which works out at $700 for every man, woman and child in this country. That is the effect of a Labor government—an extra $700 per annum for every one of us, including my two young sons who will effectively be paying another $700 a year to this government.

Not only tax but also spending is up. This government is absolutely incapable of controlling its spending. Despite all the evidence that what is required is a public sector contribution to savings, we have more government spending. Outlays excluding asset sales are up 5.4 per cent in this budget, which is about $6 1/2 billion of extra government spending. As a result, the public debt interest bill is up nearly $2 billion a year to over $10 billion per annum just on interest on the bankcard which this government has subjected us to. As my colleague Senator Vanstone pointed out in question time, we are now spending nearly as much on interest on debts racked up by this government as we spend on defending the country—an absurd situation.

The total Commonwealth debt is now over $100 billion, a figure which escapes the scope of thinking of most Australians. It is an unthinkable amount of money. It has risen $13.3 billion in the last 12 months following a similar rise in the previous year. You keep racking up the debt on the bankcard and future generations of Australians are going to have to pay for it.

Despite all that, we still have an underlying budget deficit revealed in the budget documents of $8.2 billion, which will just keep getting added to the debt. The government's smoke and mirrors trick was to flog off the silver through the asset sales of an alleged $5.3 billion, which we will believe when we see it. That is all going to recurrent expenditure, which is the equivalent of selling the backyard so you can pay for your friends to come over and have a barbecue with you. That is what this government is doing. There is absolutely no attempt to fix the underlying structural deficit in this country. When all the assets are gone, Australians will start to wonder what this government will do. There will still be the problem of a major structural deficit in the budget. The proceeds of asset sales should be going directly to reducing the massive debt which this government has been building up.

In that vein, the government should, and a coalition government will, take its lead from the South Australian state government which, among others, has made it quite clear in its budget process that asset sales will go to reduce debt. So you keep asset sales out of the budget process and delineate quite clearly recurrent income and expenditure so that you get a true picture of the state of the nation's finances. The proceeds of asset sales in South Australia are all going to reduce the debt built up by its previous state Labor government.

I commend to the Senate the remarks by Senator Gibson, who spoke prior to me, about the need to introduce accrual accounting to ensure the clear distinction between the capital account and the current account, which a coalition government will introduce.

As a South Australian senator I should and will point out the very perverse effects of this budget on South Australia. It is a direct attack on the problems in South Australia and worsens the problems in South Australia. In particular I point to the one-third increase in sales tax on cars from 16 per cent to 21 per cent. Yet another per cent will be added on 1 July to take it to 22 per cent, which will add $1,000 to the price of an average Holden or Falcon. This really does expose the unbelievably deep cynicism of this government.

The government dropped this sales tax down to 15 per cent in the lead-up to the 1993 election only because the GST of 15 per cent that we were proposing would result in cheaper motor vehicles. This panicked the government into making a sudden and electioneering drop in the sales tax rate to match our 15 per cent. Of course, at that time the government dressed it up as a permanent reduction. The word `permanent' was used by the Prime Minister. He talked about how this would help the environment by helping Australians buy more fuel efficient vehicles.

Of course, now that the election is comfortably out of the way, we learn what the word `permanent' means to Prime Minister Keating—it means absolutely nothing. This is yet another broken promise and the tax has been increased. It reinforces the point that we simply cannot believe anything this government says, and that is what will bring about this government's downfall at the next election. It used up all the political capital it had in achieving victory at the last election.

This decision in relation to sales tax on cars particularly hurts South Australia, which most honourable senators know is much more dependent on the car industry than any other state. Two out of the four manufacturers and many of the component makers for the four manufacturers are based in South Australia. Thousands of South Australians are totally dependent on the car industry for their livelihood.

In that vein, it is an utterly stupid decision. It will very badly affect South Australia, which is still suffering the consequences of years of Labor administration at state and federal level. South Australia, as this Senate knows, has a fragile economy. It has the lowest mainland growth after all those years of Labor rule and it still has a very high unemployment rate. Despite the slight drop recently, 9.7 per cent of South Australians are unemployed. That is over a full percentage point above the national rate, yet this decision will grossly affect the situation in South Australia.

The trade unions—the government's own pals and union mates—recognise the stupidity of this decision. Paul Noack, the South Australian secretary of the vehicle division of the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, has written to all of us asking us to oppose the government's tax. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Any harm this tax causes to Australia's car industry will produce a loss to our balance of trade, to employment levels, to wage tax revenue and to our manufacturing base. This potential loss far outweighs increased tax revenue on locally produced cars whose sales are seriously threatened by imports.

Mr Noack goes on to ask us to oppose this tax. I am happy to declare here and now that my colleagues and I will vote against this stupid increase in the tax. We will also vote against the increases in the company tax, the sales tax on building materials and the Medicare levy.

PARA.TAB: This really is a king hit on South Australia. It follows the damage done by this government to South Australia in the 1993 budget when it brought in the increases in wine tax. If there are two industries that matter to South Australia they are the wine industry and the car industry. This government in the last two years has king-hit both those industries in the most fragile state economy on the mainland. The government clearly has absolutely no sensitivity to the regional problems in South Australia.

This really highlights one of the major problems with current Labor Party economic policy. It has just one macro-economic policy for six different state economies. There are six economies in this country, despite the government's centralist pretensions. One only has to look at the different growth rates, the different unemployment rates and the different activity rates in the six states to know that that is a fact of life. Government policy is deliberately designed now to slow down the Australian economy. It is deliberately trying to slow down growth and it is doing that by maintaining high real interest rates and high taxation, which I have just outlined.

High growth may well be a problem in Queensland and Western Australia, but I can tell you that South Australians wish they had that problem. It is hardly a problem in South Australia where, as I said, after so many years of an inept Labor government we have the lowest growth rate on the mainland. What South Australia needs is incentives to growth—not crushing policies out of a centralised approach in Canberra dealing with the non-existent national economy. The answer is a much more responsible macro-economic policy which is much more sensitive to the fact that we have six economies in this country.

I hope a coalition government will introduce the equivalent of New Zealand's Fiscal Responsibility Act. There should be much more emphasis on adequate and appropriate micro-economic policy. We need reforms to reduce the cost pressures on business and reforms to increase our competitiveness.

It is appropriate that today John Prescott, the head of our biggest and most successful company, has highlighted the real problems in this area. He said that there is clear evidence of reform fatigue in this government. As he said, the cost disadvantages that many companies in this country are facing are greatest on the waterfront and in rail freight for which the Labor government has direct responsibility. He said that government and port authority charges for containers at our most competitive port, Fremantle, were 2 1/2 times those applying in Singapore. Container charges in Melbourne were 40 per cent higher than that. Charges to get a car into Melbourne were quoted at $73.92 in 1992, the highest in Australia, whereas to get a car into Seattle cost $10.48—one-seventh of the cost of Melbourne—and to get a car into Osaka cost $13.91.

How can this country compete when you have cost differentials like that which you are doing nothing about? Industrial relations reform is essential in allowing this country to be competitive, to grow and to create jobs. Again, you are doing nothing about that.

I am delighted that your Labor colleague Premier Carr has drawn attention to the idiocy of your unfair dismissal laws, which put the onus totally on the employer and are an anti-employment policy. One would think they are designed to discourage people from employing extra staff. It is a nonsense, and I applaud Bob Carr for drawing attention to the stupidity of those laws.

I would like to record my deep regret at the government's failure in this budget to do anything about a matter which I and many of my colleagues have spoken about; that is, the discrimination this government is maintaining against mothers of young children who have sacrificed an income to care for their children at home. Despite all the evidence of the discrimination which we have brought to the parliament's attention, despite the community activity on this subject and despite the Cass report which resulted from the government's very own National Council for the International Year of the Family and which highlighted the discriminatory operation of government policy, the government has done absolutely nothing.

If we are to believe press reports, there was considerable anxiety and division within the government on this issue. But, clearly, there was a stalemate and a failure to do anything. So the discrimination continues to exist. It exists in the fact that a mother of two in the paid work force who places her children in child care will receive twice as much from the government as a mother of two young children caring for them at home. That is the bald fact. They receive twice as much. There is no income test for the mother in the paid work force with her children in child care who receives money under the child-care cash rebate. She can earn a million dollars a year and she will still receive support from the government. However, there is a quite severe income test on what was the home child-care allowance which has now been converted to the parenting allowance.

I have noted that the income test has been eased and the mother at home can now earn $30 a week. I am delighted to see that that threshold has been increased. But I note that what is now called the parenting allowance is reduced by 50c for every extra dollar you earn in the range $30 to $70 and then by 70c for every dollar above $70 a week. The income test remains in comparison to the non-existent income test under the CCR quite prohibitive and quite severe. The discrimination and bias remains.

As John Howard made quite clear in his magnificent speech this week on the role of government, the point is that the issue is choice. The government should not arbitrarily and unfairly interfere with the choice which young mothers make about their work and child-care arrangements. Current policy directly interferes in that choice and directs it in one direction. There is not free choice for young mothers.

I note that expenditure on this child-care cash rebate, which has been subject to much criticism within the government, is increasing by 31 per cent in this forthcoming year to $118 million, out of a total of $1,107 million on child care. It is the worst form of middle-class welfare. We advocated at the time it was brought in that it should be means tested, subject to an income test and subject to the same test applying to the family payments system.

I draw attention to the budget increase in the tobacco excise, which is clearly nothing more than revenue raising by the government. It is predicted to raise an extra $70 million in 1995-96. Most of this is taken out of the pockets of what has been described this week as that class of Australians called battlers. Many of the three million Australians who regularly smoke are battlers. I have never smoked in my life and I am not here to defend the act of smoking, but these Australians, many of whom are on very low incomes and whose one joy in life is smoking, are now being hit yet again by this latest government impost. It is these battlers who will pay this extra tax, and they are saying, quite rightly, `Enough is enough.'

It is interesting to trace what has happened on the tobacco tax. The government laid out a plan for tobacco excise increases in 1993 with six monthly increases of five per cent finalising in a five per cent increase in August of this year. The government in the budget brought that five per cent increase due in August 1995 forward to budget night, doubled it to 10 per cent and said to all three million Australians who smoke, `Tough luck,' catching all the smokers and the tobacco companies completely unaware in a most capricious, unfair and unjustifiable manner.

There has been a 35 per cent increase in the tobacco excise since August 1993. It is by far the most heavily taxed consumer product in Australia. The budget night increase is completely unwarranted and unacceptable. The government should stick to the program of budget increases that it announced in 1993. The next and final increase should be five per cent in August 1995 and not the 10 per cent that occurred on budget night.

In summary, this budget is a complete failure. It fails to deal with our major economic problems, it has ignored them completely. It is a political document to get the government through the election. It fails to deal with the massive foreign debt of $160,000 we have incurred under this government. It fails to deal with the problem of the current account deficit, budgeted to be again $27,000 million in this financial year. It fails to deal with this country's very low savings ratio. It fails to deal with the fact that we still have 800,000 Australians without a job. It fails to deal with what are still among the highest real interest rates in the Western world.

The ultimate failure is this government's admission that it cannot allow the Australian economy to grow fast enough to reduce unemployment to acceptable levels. If it tries to grow at a speed which will allow unemployment to be reduced to acceptable levels, the wheels fall off the economy, the bus starts to rattle and we run off the road. That is the ultimate indictment of this government's economic policy. Instead of fiddling around with our constitution, the government should spend its final few months before it is turfed out of office trying to repair the damage that it has done over the last 12 years to the Australian economy.

—Wasting time, like you do all the time.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate Senator Minchin on an excellent speech. I also comment that he and I followed some excellent contributions from Senator Brian Gibson and Senator Paul Calvert, both of whom are very active Liberal senators from my home state of Tasmania.

The appropriation bills seek to implement the government's budgetary process and undo the fraud which was perpetrated by Labor on the Australian people at the last election. This budget hurts all Australians, but it especially hurts the struggling families and small businesses.

One thing I want to debunk at the outset is the assertion that the government has been running round with that there is somehow a $700 million surplus in this budget. Although it takes a very long time to find, if we read through budget paper No. 1—quite a thick volume—and we go about nine-tenths of the way through, on page 7.3 we see that there is a table called `Table 2—Adjusted ABS budget deficit'. That tells us the true story—that, in fact, there is an $8.2 billion deficit in this budget. That is something that needs to be debunked. The people of Australia need to be advised at all times that this is not a surplus budget but, as ABS points out, an $8.2 billion deficit budget.

Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in a slip of the tongue acknowledged that the surplus was a psychological surplus. In other words, the government wanted the view, the perception, within the community that the budget was somehow in surplus when, in fact, the reality is that it is not in surplus.

The situation is that we as Australians have suffered under this Labor government by its extravagant expenditure. We have now come to the end of the road where we can just borrow over and over again to fund all the pet projects of this government and then have the government trying to rebuy or repurchase an electoral mandate on every single occasion it goes to the polls. There is a limit to how much we can borrow; we have arrived at that limit.

So what does the government do? To keep on with the profligate lifestyle it has embarked upon, it starts to sell off the family silver. Most people would not object if assets were sold to pay off debt that has been incurred. But what this government has done is sell assets to keep on with the profligate lifestyle that it has adopted.

Somehow during question time in the week since the budget, we have been told that this sort of strategy is a caring, warm, compassionate approach to budgetary matters as opposed to that being experienced by our neighbours in New Zealand. Let me say that yes, it does ease the lifestyle for the Prime Minister and all those who might be in the chamber or elsewhere whose life expectancy might not be very great. But I tell this house and the people of Australia that there is no compassion, no concern, when I know that my three young children will be responsible for paying off the debts which have been incurred by Mr Keating and his government over the past 12 to 13 years.

That is a shameful situation. I know that when my children have to face the burden of the extravagance of the Labor era, they will not be talking about it in terms of it being caring and compassionate. They will be talking about it in absolute anger, because their rightful inheritance has been sold off for electoral frauds perpetrated by Mr Keating. Well may Mr Keating talk about giving Australia some degree of independence and a republic to allow Australians to determine their own future: the simple fact is that my children will not be able to determine their own economic future because Mr Keating has already mortgaged it.

The reality is that my three children owe $12,000 each overseas. Every single man, woman and child carries a debt of $12,000 each. The members of the public gallery might like to reflect on that as well: you owe $12,000 each. If the international bailiff were to come along and say, `We want that $12,000 out of each Australian,' how would we repay that? Each of us would have to make significant and devastating sacrifices. That is for one reason alone: because of the extravagance of the Australian Labor Party. There is, as I said before, nothing caring or compassionate about mortgaging the future of my children and their friends.

The Labor government has sought to tell us that it will make this a budget in surplus by the sale of assets. Let us just remember that, over the last three years, the government has managed to sell only $3.3 billion worth of assets. This is the fourth occasion on which Qantas has been in the budget papers to be sold. This is the fourth attempt that Labor has had to try to sell Qantas. Of course, the Commonwealth Bank sale is in defiance of undertakings given by Labor. Every indication is that the Commonwealth Bank sale was rushed into the budget at the very last moment to give us what the Treasurer accidentally called the `psychological surplus'.

This budget is a budget of tax hikes. It may be worth while to list some of the taxes, because virtually each and every one of them that I will list is a complete repudiation of Labor Party promises. The first one, of course, came about when St Carmen—as the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is sometimes known—came into the federal parliament and became the minister for health with a great degree of fanfare. One of her first undertakings was: `There will be no increase in the Medicare levy.' She was absolutely firm. Her credibility was to be determined on that undertaking. The people of Australia will surely make a determination on that, because the Medicare levy has been increased from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent. Another broken promise.

We can go to the taxes on building materials, which will cause a substantial increase in the cost of housing. Senator Tambling, the shadow minister for housing, is in the chamber nodding his head. To his very great credit, he has highlighted that over past weeks.

The simple fact is that the great Australian dream is to be able to own your own home and, as a result of Labor's tax increases, that will now be so much further out of reach for the average Australian. We are not only talking about new houses; we are also talking about renovations to houses. Some people might want just to upgrade their kitchen, which is so often the nerve centre of family living. That will become more expensive and, as a result, out of the reach of families.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

PARA.TAB: Then, we had the much heralded 1 January 1996 tax cuts. Remember l-a-w, law? They were in law. They were not some promise like John Hewson was promising. Paul Keating had already legislated these tax cuts. But the l-a-w turned into the big l-i-e. Those tax cuts have been abolished—another broken promise.

Customs tax is up by $110 million; excise is up by $952 million; and sales tax is up a massive $2.58 billion, including the sales tax on new cars that Senator Minchin so ably addressed in his contribution to this debate. This sales tax increase is nothing other than a GST in disguise. It is the same sort of approach that Paul Keating was frothing at the mouth about during the last election. One wonders why he railed and ranted so strongly against a goods and services tax when he is now taxing these goods of Australians, such as new cars, higher than we on this side were proposing at that time. We can then move to individuals and the PAYE tax, which is up a staggering $6.1 billion. For individuals who do not pay PAYE tax, it is up $1.38 billion. Company tax is up $2.29 billion. It is worth noting, as Senator Minchin said, that the tax rate on cars was dropped just to match opposition policy for the last election. Now that that is over, the government has increased it and that is exactly what happened with company tax. We proposed a lower rate of tax for companies to make them more viable so that they could compete effectively and provide a stimulus for employment. We know that we need stimulus for employment in this country because of the outrageous unemployment rate that this country has suffered under the Labor government.

So what did Labor do in relation to company tax to match the Liberal Party? It said, `We will reduce it.' But it was for Liberal Party reasons. It was to make our Australian companies more competitive with Asia because we were going to get into Asia and really make a go of things. We were going to go gang busters into Asia, as I recall the Prime Minister said. The tax rates in Asia have not changed. The very reason that the Prime Minister advanced for the reduction in company taxation is now being jettisoned to try to get more money back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or New Zealand.

—In fact, Senator Parer tells me New Zealand is going to reduce it even further. We see the New Zealand economy blossoming. Therefore, the price the consumer pays goes up and the amount of money left in the pockets of average Australians is thereby substantially reduced. Their spending power is reduced and their capacity to stimulate the economy is reduced.

Labor somehow believes that the more you tax the better it is for the economy. We on this side of the chamber believe that the best way to stimulate the economy is to get Paul Keating's hand out of our pockets and out of our fellow Australians' pockets and let our fellow Australians determine where they want to spend their money for the benefit of the community and for the benefit of business generally.

I will mention briefly a few matters that I feel very strongly about. Within this budget there is a proposal to cut the expenditure for Senate committees by a considerable sum—namely, 27 per cent. That will have a direct impact on the capacity of this house to effectively undertake its duties and responsibilities. For a Keating government that is so interested in calling us unrepresentative swill and for the Labor Party that used to have in its policy the abolition of this chamber, what better way of achieving that result than by neutering us and by withholding funds to ensure that we cannot undertake the work that we are required to undertake by the people of Australia.

In relation to Tasmania, let me say that I was disappointed that when a number of new places in universities were made available for those people living in regional and far flung areas of Australia they were only made available to the states of Queensland and Western Australia. There is no doubt that those states deserve that funding and need it. The University of Tasmania made a very modest request for 20 to 30 places out of the thousands that were being created by this scheme.

All we wanted was 20 or 30 places for the north-west coast of my home state of Tasmania. Tasmania as a whole has a very low participation rate in tertiary education, but the north-west coast of that state has the lowest level within Tasmania. It is clearly a very deprived area in relation to involvement in tertiary education. The University of Tasmania will be setting up a centre on the north-west coast in September of this year. Its very modest request for 20 to 30 places has been denied. I note that Senator Sherry, who makes a lot of fanfare about representing the north-west coast of Tasmania, is in the chamber and remains silent. I trust that Senator Sherry will make representations to ensure that Tasmania gets its fair share.

This government wasted $1.5 million on the National Media Liaison Service, which is the government's propaganda arm. You know the $20 note you have in your wallet which, if you are lucky enough, will still be there if Paul Keating has not taken it off you already—the government had a $1 million program to promote that within Australia. What a waste of money. It spent $250,000 on the Cleo sex guide. What a waste of money. There is a huge list of things where the government has wasted money. The inquiry into draining Lake Pedder was a waste of money. The only good thing about this budget is that it will surely be Labor's last.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly want to deal with sales tax because sales tax demonstrates the lie to its greatest degree. Sales tax is a consumption tax. It is the tax the Labor Party would not wear. The Labor Party attacked violently the whole concept of consumption tax during the last federal election campaign. Yet since that time there has been this massive increase in sales taxes—the greatest increase in sales tax revenue in Australia's history, lifting sales tax revenue to its highest proportion of gross domestic product ever.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the history of sales tax—this tax that the Labor government opposed violently and on which it is now relying more and more for its revenue. I think the government will be collecting something like $14 billion from this sneaky consumption tax which is on almost everything that most Australians pay for, even some foods. Sales tax, interestingly enough, and I suppose it is natural, was first introduced into Australia by a Labor government with effect from 1 August 1930. This tax the Labor Party violently opposes as a dreadful consumption tax was introduced by Labor, has been increased by Labor, has been used by Labor and has been the basis upon which Labor has mounted a deceptive and dishonest campaign against a reform of that consumption tax during the last election campaign.

Only a few countries maintain the operation of a wholesale sales tax along Labor's lines. Australia is the only developed country persevering with the operation of this tax—Labor's sales tax, as I said, introduced by Labor. Naturally you can trust Labor when it introduces a tax not to increase it—much! When it was first introduced it was 2.5 per cent. Only a year later the then Prime Minister increased it to six per cent. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Generally, the tax—
that is, sales tax—

has proved most unsatisfactory, but I recognise it is inevitable that we should not only continue to impose it but should increase the rate from 2.5 per cent to six per cent. That alone is sufficient to indicate the unfortunate financial position of Australia.

He was so right. It is exactly the same now. Here, once again, Australia is in what could politely be described as an `unfortunate financial position' as a result of this government's incompetence. How is the government solving it? By whacking up sales tax—Labor's own tax. What did Mr Chifley, Labor's icon, have to say when he tried to improve the sales tax system? This is back in the 1940s when he reduced the number of different scales of sales tax—it had been three. He said:

It is recognised that considerable work is involved in the classification of goods into three separate groups and it is hoped that a substantial measure of relief will be afforded by the reduction in the number of rates of tax from three to two.

So what is Labor doing? I suppose Ben Chifley would be rolling in his grave because the current rates of sales tax are as follows: there is one lot at nil; there is one lot at 11 per cent; there is another lot at 16 per cent; there is another lot at 21 per cent; there is another lot at 24 per cent; there is another lot at 31 per cent; and another lot at 45 per cent.

PARA.TAB: There is Mr Chifley saying, `You mustn't have this big range of sales taxes' and what does this government do? Exactly the opposite, because this government believes in secretly ripping off the ordinary battlers of Australia by hitting them where they cannot see it, by putting taxes on things like toilet paper, soap, ice-cream and so on that they do not realise exist. As if that is not bad enough—this huge range of different categories of sales tax, which involves a whole lot of very convenient prosecutions for the government as the tax office keeps fining small businesses, in particular, for putting the wrong rate of sales tax on whatever it is they are selling—these rates are to go up from 1 July.

The secret, sneaky Labor tax goes up again at the end of this month. Instead of the figures I have mentioned, taxes will rise 12 per cent, 17 per cent, 22 per cent, 26 per cent and 32 per cent—while the 45 per cent rate remains unchanged. All those sneaky, secret sales tax rises take place at the end of this month. Would you trust Labor with any tax? You certainly would not trust it with tax promises. What happens once the taxes are in? Up they go. These taxes are simply and

SPEECH.PARA: incontrovertibly placed on business, particularly small business, and on personal consumption.

PARA.TAB: I am indebted to a booklet called The Sales Tax Challenge, put out by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia and written by David Vos FCA. This book reveals the disgraceful performance that this government has undertaken in the matter of sales tax. The booklet says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . based on 1993/94 statistics published by the ATO, it is apparent that motor vehicles, parts and accessories, household appliances—
they are not items of the rich; everyone has household appliances—
furnishings and hardware, machinery and equipment and beer, wine and spirits account for almost 75% of total sales tax revenue.
As we have seen, it is bursting up. The study also says:
. . . Australia still collects a disproportionately higher amount of revenue from personal income tax than most other OECD countries . . .
Unless significant reform is made to the existing wholesale sales tax then the dominance of taxation revenue from incomes will only become more marked:
It concludes:
Much needs to be done to overhaul the wholesale sales tax. The Federal Government needs to show leadership and reconstruct the taxing base from scratch.

Before the government can do that, it has to tell the truth. It would not want to do that, would it? It keeps hiding its disgraceful record of sneaky tax rises. Then, showing its level of deception, it attacked an attempt by the coalition at the last election to do it honestly and openly.

PARA.TAB: It is secretly lifting consumption taxes because, frankly, it has to. It would much rather do it by deception, because that is its style. You deceive people at the election and then you sneakily put your hands in their pockets and whack the money out by way of sales tax rises without having the honesty to say what you are doing.

The Treasurer of three years ago, just before the last election, said that he was going to try to fix things up. He announced that the government had agreed to a major series of measures to simplify and improve Australia's wholesale sales tax. Simplify? In a pig's ear! I suppose that is appropriate in view of the Prime Minister's enthusiasm about pigs. The booklet also says:

SPEECH.PARA: Although originally heralded as the simplified sales tax, the word "simplification" was subsequently changed to "streamlined".
The officer in charge of the simplification program of the wholesale sales tax indicated:
"Simplification was the wrong word . . . A better term would be modernisation of the law or rationalisation."
There has certainly been no simplification. It has got worse and worse, bigger and bigger and more deceptive and more deceptive.

PARA.TAB: A research study, published by the Australian Tax Research Foundation, of 1993 found:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the majority of taxpayers (approximately 85% with annual sales tax liabilities of less than $50,000) incurred a compliance cost of nearly 25% of tax paid.

In other words, on top of the tax, they had the huge cost of filling in the forms, collecting them and sending them in—a 25 per cent added cost burden to small businesses. They are the people with annual sales tax liabilities of less than $50,000. It is small business that this government is hitting hardest with this deceptive Labor sales tax—introduced by Labor, reinforced by Labor and increased by Labor. Now it is the fastest rising tax in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is certainly no simplification here if compliance costs are 25 per cent for small business. It is a bit simpler for the tax man to operate—not for small business people, taxpayers, who have to foot the bill. SPEECH.PARA: This is a ridiculous situation and is counterproductive to the development of small business. It creates a huge and unnecessary hurdle for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other people affected by this tax are those in business. There is a huge input cost on business. As a study points out, more than half of the initial incidence of wholesale sales tax is on business inputs. In the end consumers have to pay, but businesses are trying to compete with overseas and are having to pay something like 49 per cent for initial sales tax costs. This burden is passed on to consumers by businesses. However, foreign companies—the companies that some of our companies are competing with—do not have that kind of burden. It is a disincentive to business. It is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: This government has done absolutely nothing to stop that. In fact, it is like a carrion crow feeding off the people of Australia, the businesses of Australia, the battlers of Australia, the small businesses of Australia, the ordinary consumers of Australia, with this hidden, sneaky sales tax which the government pretended it opposed. It is Labor's consumption tax. As Senator Abetz said, it is the government's own secret GST. That is what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few things to this debate on the appropriation bills. What I would mostly like to add relates to the non-appropriations by this government. I do not have the time to go into all of those non-appropriations in this year's budget and these bills, but I will go into one aspect: drought relief around Australia.

PARA.TAB: Recently, there has been an increase in drought relief to northern New South Wales, parts of Queensland and parts of Victoria. I am glad that at last the government is accepting that drought has a big effect on the state of the Australian economy. When the Hawke government was first elected in 1983, it would never recognise that the reason the economy was down at the end of the Fraser government was the massive drought the eastern states had in 1982 and the drought that followed in Western Australia in 1983. It was a very big, hard, long drought to go through.

The eastern states drought of last year was almost as bad. The government recognised that fact and through the drought relief, which I welcome, made available low interest loans, household support, et cetera. I, along with all my colleagues, said that that aid was nowhere near what was required. With the massive population in New South Wales, the bottom of Queensland and the top of Victoria, this government finally listened to their plight and did come up with a certain amount. It then followed up with some more aid in this budget.

It is interesting to hear what Senator Gareth Evans, who represents the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this place, has to say when the balance of trade figures are not as good as expected. On half a dozen occasions in the last few weeks, he has blamed the drought for those figures. Everyone in the Labor government has always refused to acknowledge the drought at the end of the Fraser years. Former Senator Button was always comparing the situation of the economy but he would never answer an interjection of mine, `What about the drought of 1982?' Finally the government is admitting that drought does knock around the economy and Australia's export income. That is very interesting.

While the government has recognised the eastern states, it has completely left the Western Australian drought affected areas of East Gascoyne and Murchison out in the cold. I did a big tour of those regions in around mid-March, just before Cyclone Bobby went through. Although they had a very wet season in 1989, they have had continuous years of no rain, let alone little rain, ever since. There was mostly cattle in those areas, and the cattle numbers went down and down.

If you look at the pastoral industry in Western Australia in the Gascoyne, Murchison and Kimberley regions—there is also some pastoral industry in the Pilbara region, which is where most of Australia's iron ore is mined—you will find that not one station has gone into liquidation since the inception of the pastoral industry in those areas, and to my knowledge the pastoral industry started there in about the 1880s. They were resilient people; they are still resilient people. While those pastoralists are in this situation, the government should do something to help them such as offer them low interest loans or what could be better described as an interest subsidy.

There are not many people in this place who may know that those pastoralists in those areas can never borrow from a banking institution. The simple reason is the tenure of the property of those pastoralists. They are on finite leases and they will all expire in the year 2015. Whether they will be renewed in 2015 will have a lot to do with the Native Title Act, which went through this parliament some time back. But that is not the debate at hand today. We will have plenty of opportunities down the track to debate that. Because the pastoralists' properties are on finite leases—the banking institutions will not take a station as collateral—they have to borrow on the stock at hand: cattle, sheep or whatever they may have.

The only lending institutions for that are the stockbrokers—for example, Elders, Wesfarmers in Western Australia and Dalgety or whatever it is called over here. They are the only ones. Those institutions have to charge higher interest because they do not have the access to low interest money that the banking institutions have. So those pastoralists are in a harder position than most other pastoralists or farmers who have to borrow.

The government continually refuses to help them. I have spoken to Senator Bob Collins about the situation at various times. I have spoken in this place. The Western Australian government has taken the issue up for those people. Over the last five years, they have had four years of almost nil rainfall. So their stock numbers have got down to 25 per cent. A few stations received stewardship grants, which are about $20,000. That amount means nothing to stations of that size. Mind you, when things are running normally, these stations turn out 5,000, 6,000 or 7,000 head of cattle per year. They are not small figures.

What is more, they are taking up that very important export market of live cattle. One of the reasons there are more and more live cattle going out of Western Australia is that the abattoirs of the north have closed. The antiquated industrial relations system took all the abattoirs out. I believe the only abattoir working now in all of the pastoral industry of Western Australia is at Broome. The nearest one is in Geraldton, or in Perth or in Katherine in the Northern Territory. So they are in a very tight economic situation.

Worse still for them, as far as the economic situation is concerned, is that they have had these drought-breaking rains, up to 12 or 15 inches in some places—Halls Creek has had 30 to 40 inches, but I am talking more about Gascoyne and Murchison—there is feed as high as this table and they do not have enough cattle. You would think the government would have some commonsense. It does not matter about compassion; leave the compassion bit out. The commonsense approach is that the low interest subsidy could be put into those places. A hundredfold reward would then be reaped when they start moving their cattle out again.

Beyond those stations is the big danger that we will lose those markets in South-East Asia. The Prime Minister keeps telling us that our direction is towards South-East Asia. I agree with him that more and more trade with them, without selling our souls, is all the better for us. They are right on our doorstep. But if we lose those live cattle markets to, say, South America or even America itself—and they like their live cattle—the only other viable place is South America.

If we were to start losing our markets to those places, we would be in trouble. Would it be beyond the realms of possibility that the government could still do something for them now, otherwise we will miss out on many opportunities down the line? I am asking the government to look at that issue again.

In the brief time available to me, I would like to look at federal government financial assistance grants to local government. As a result of this budget, we are about to get a bill which seeks to alter the system of financial assistance grants to local governments around Australia because the 1986 agreement runs out on 30 June this year. We will have a chance to debate that issue in the weeks to come.

I would like to point out to the chamber and the rest of Australia that, under this new legislation, general purpose grants will continue to be separately identified. That is something I have always wanted. This government has gone away from untied grants to local government. Most of my colleagues accepted the untied grants. I certainly never did, and I have been proved to be right. There were only two or three of us who did not accept those untied grants. This new legislation seeks to have those general purpose grants separately identified, and there is a move to tie them too.

What worries me is that, when these grants are distributed to state government commissions, the interest rates will still be done by those state government commissions but the allocations will be performed on the basis of national principles declared by the federal minister. I am afraid that we will have another Kelly whiteboard situation if this is not looked at carefully. I urge those people who wish to talk on those bills to look at that. I can assure you that in the weeks and months to come I will make sure that we will not go down that line as directed by the federal minister. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill, together with the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1995 (the Charge Bill), completes the package of legislative measures introduced last year following the Government's 1994 Budget initiative to replace the existing $25 departure tax with a $27 passenger movement charge (PMC) to fully offset the cost of customs, immigration and quarantine processing at Australia's borders and the cost of issuing short-term visitor visas.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation passed by the Parliament last year as Acts Nos. 146 and 159 of 1994 set the new rate of charge at $27 in respect of departures from Australia after 1 January 1995. At the time that legislation was being considered by the Parliament, the Government also made known its intention to commence negotiations with international air and sea passenger carriers to have them collect the PMC as part of their ticketing arrangements, thereby removing the need for departure tax stamp booths at international departure points.

Negotiations with airlines are in their final stages and the airlines' representatives have given their in principle agreement for the airlines to enter into arrangements to collect PMC from passengers departing after 1 July 1995. For the first 12 months of the new collection regime, when airlines will still be establishing collection procedures, the PMC stamp booths will remain at international airports to ensure that those passengers who have not prepaid the PMC as part of the price of a ticket will be able to pay before departing Australia. The airlines understand that at the end of this transitional period the booths will cease to operate and the airlines will assume sole responsibility for PMC collection. A further arrangement will be negotiated with the airlines for the long term.

As part of the new collection regime, this bill will replace the existing 24 narrowly defined categories of exemption from PMC liability with 12 broadly defined categories of exemption; both to facilitate collection of the PMC by airlines and shipping companies and to clarify the operation of the new collection scheme. In particular, item 4 of the Schedule to the bill provides that a person departing from Australia will not have to pay the $27 PMC in relation to his or her departure, where that person is:

PARA.TAB: under 12 years of age; or
a traditional inhabitant of the Torres Strait travelling in connection with traditional activities; or
a member of the defence force of another country (or that person's family) who departs from Australia in the course of their duty on a military aircraft or ship; or
the crew member of an aircraft or ship, or a member of their family, or a crew member who is being repositioned; or
a passenger who is in transit, or departs Australia after entering because of an emergency or other circumstance beyond his or her control; or
a foreign diplomatic or consular staff member; or
a passenger on a cruise-type journey which involves multiple departures from Australia, where the PMC has already been paid in respect of a previous departure during the course of that journey; or
a person travelling to Area A of the Australia—Indonesia Zone of Cooperation in the Timor Sea in accordance with the Timor Gap Treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: This final category has been included as a consequence of the amendment in the Charge bill to treat departures for installations in Area A in the same way as departures for other countries as both require customs and immigration processing. Persons departing in connection with petroleum exploration activities have been exempted from PMC on the same basis as ship and aircraft crew members, namely, that the departure is undertaken in the course of their employment.

The measures in the Charge bill clarify the treatment of travel involving Australia's external Territories and bring the status of departures to installations in Area A of the Australia—Indonesia Zone of Cooperation into line with that in the Customs Act 1901 and the Migration Act 1958.

PARA.TAB: (i) redefinition of transit passengers—increase for 1995-96 of $1.5 million;
(ii) abolition of various exemptions—increase for 1995-96 of $300,000.
